I have stayed here when I felt quite alone, but even with hundreds of people checking in during the time I was here, the hotel was an oasis.

The hotel was used as our base for the Rugby World Cup 2019 whilst in Tokyo. We found the hotel to be comfortable and efficient with the staff being friendly and helpful. The bedroom was comfortable and quite spacious. The buffet breakfast was excellent. Most staff spoke English which made things easy. Now to the poor bit! Whilst we were there Typhoon Hagibis struck Tokyo and the surrounding area which caused both Tokyo airports to be closed. As a result of this our return flights were cancelled and we were left trying to source accommodation for 2 extra nights. Initial enquiries with reception were not fruitful as we were told the hotel was fully booked but keep asking as the situation might change. Indeed it did change 1 hour before we were due to check outing we were informed that we could stay in our room. This would have been great had Hilton not asked a frankly ridiculous amount of money. 80,000 Yen which was nearly double what we had paid for the room on the 6 preceding nights. This just felt like blatant profiteering and taking advantage of a challenging situation. So to sum up, my thanks to the staff who looked after us during our stay but out of principle I will not stay in a Hilton hotel again.

A lovely hotel - stayed through the typhoon and staff were exceptional and made me think of the titanic - everyone served as though it was a perfectly normal day and yet the worse typhoon in 60 years was rattling the windows and presumably they all had families to worry about - room nice but not fancy - perfectly ok size and amenities - but the restaurants were so good - chinese was exceptional and japanese perfect

Hilton was our base for a 2 week trip for the Rugby world cup. We had a room on the 25th floor, it was a good size bed was a touch hard for my tastes.The breakfast was good though repetitive after a few days. The staff always helpful and friendly.Very well located with subway station under hotel, and Shinjuku station a brisk 10 minute walk away.It is Tokyo and it is a Hilton, so if you do eat or drink there, be prepared to pay for it. We were trapped by the typhoon and paid over £100 for a very average buffet.However the sky bar showing the rugby was a great idea and worked well.Generally we had a good stay.

I stayed at Tokyo Hilton for two nights on a business trip in October 2019. The reservation went smoothly, front desk personnel was kind and effective, I got a room (3429) even with my very early and unexpected arrival. Because I got to the hotel early in the morning I was given a room from a smokers floor. I was told this prior to me accepting the room and guaranteed there would not be any odors. Well, not 100% accurate, but still very ok. Hilton key system with a mobile app worked wonderfully, my room was pleasantly big and everything you could ask for in a basic business class hotel was as guaranteed. Still very pricey, as business hotels in Tokyo are. The hotel has a decent pool and big enough gym with free weights, machines and treadmills. That was certainly a pleasant surprise. Hotel itself is conveniently connected to an underground mall and hotel has several restaurants and bars, even a cigar bar.

Great Hotel - Would highly recommend! My wife and I were here for business. The staff was very professional and helpful. The room was very clean, comfortable and quiet. The location was near transit. The hotel offered shuttle buses to various areas and also a shuttle to the airport. We highly rated this hotel.

The hotel is very nice, and very clean. The rooms are great. But the staff... oh boy... the staff. Yea, the staff just about ruin this hotel. They are very condescending. Also Make sure to factor in 30 minutes for elevator travel time, and prepare yourself to feel like a sardine every time you need to use it, even though there are at least four elevators it doesn’t seem like they all get used. Are you diamond status? Because the employees on the executive lounge won’t care much and will still act like your trash. Craving a very generic buffet? Oh well, that starts at 70 bucks. Want a room service burger? Oh well, that’ll be 36 bucks for a burger and fries. Trapped on site because of a typhoon ? Well get ready to be fully exploited because your only options are to eat in the hotel and sell your kidneys to pay for dinner.

Fabulously clean hotel with polite service which is well located - Breakfast buffet excellent! Pricey mind - £75 for 2x burger and chips plus cokes is taking the rise. Lack of lounge to sit and read/rest; it seems this is called your room. Good hotel but be prepared for being treated as an asset from which value needs to be attained, I get that at work and would like to have had a different experience whilst away on holiday; there were many examples of this to the extent it became a bit tiresome. To end on a positive do utilise the gym and sauna/hot spa facilities which are good and do allow for time to rest/relax without extra charge.

Rugby World cup in style. Hotel was perfect, staff were incredible and given they were completely full handled everything with professionalism ,grace and great humour. Love our time at the hotel, would certainly come back again, business or pleasure

Despite the busy rugby season, everything was excellent. Apart from the busy elevators, nothing to complain. But couldn’t be different. The City was really busy. I had a problem with my laptop and the IT specialist helped me to fix it. Excellent client service experience. The rooms at fresh and comfortable. Loads of choices to eat, shopping and a great barber shop in the building. Definitely an excellent place to stay,

Good location and an easy walk or complimentary bus or metro from the main Shinjuku train station. Check in was smooth and we were upgraded to a nice suite as Diamond members. Lounge was good with nice views of the city and of Mt Fuji on two days. There was also a soft drinks fridge which also included beer all day long! Complimentary snacks in the happy hour were also good. Breakfast in the lounge was fine although the main ground floor restaurant was over crowded with quite long queues. The main bar on the first flor was a bit too noisy for our tastes and the bar on the ground floor surprisingly allows smoking. Staff were helpful though and set us up a nice table just outside the bar. Our room was good with some international TV channels but like most of Japan it seems the bathroom was surprisingly small. Nice bath and shower - use small! Overall I’d recommend and a good but large city hotel.

We stayed here for the Rugby World Cup while Typhoon Hagibis battered Tokyo. The staff were amazing. We were locked in from 3.00pm and the staff looked after several hundred guests throughout the day with great charm and patience. The eye of the storm passed over the hotel at 21.00 and there was bright sunshine by the time we woke up the following morning. The hotel itself works well. The rooms are small but the beds are large and comfy. When the hotel is busy, the lifts are slow. We ate in the Chinese restaurant one evening. It was expensive but excellent. Sadly, there was no duck on the menu as they had already fled on advance of the typhoon. The buffet breakfast caters to all tastes.

We were desperate to find a safe haven for the night of the typhoon and finally a room came up here on Booking. com. Sure, it was well overpriced but we were happy to have a place to stay and somewhere to rest after a pretty hectic day. Knowing a bit about the hotel industry, I am taking the time to write this review as we were welcomed by Ernesto, Argentinian gentleman, who I understand is Front Desk Management. When he saw us waiting to check in quickly responded, answered our questions and he and his staff had a very lonnngg day to ensure everyone's wellbeing and sense of security. He was there when we checked in and still there late into the evening and his professionalism and customer service did not go unnoticed. Thank you.

It is very convenient for the subway and getting around and the food from the various restaurants is very good, but the hotel itself is tired and uninspiring. We are diamond members and had access to the Executive lounge which again was nothing special.

Starting with the good points the hotel is close to the subway and there is a free shuttle to Shinjuku. On the negative it is not children friendly, it is outrageously expensive to eat and drink and the hotel still thinks it’s ok to charge for internet, something free in almost ever other hotel in the world. Given the abundance of choice I would not stay here again.

Hilton is all show and no go. It is an impressive hotel with large, well maintained bedrooms but scratch the surface and it all is not as pretty as it seems. As a luxury hotel I expected something more but I've stayed in 3 star hotels in Japan offering similar standards for a lot, lot less. My particular bugbear, but not the only gripe, is their predilection for charging service fees on everything. Get a room upgrade, expect to get hit with a 13% service charge despite no mention of this. Get room service and bang there we go again. Everything has a hidden 13% smashed on top - and this in the heart of no tipping Japan. I stayed for six days and this adds up. And they don't take nicely to requests to remove it for poor service or pointing out it's not mentioned anywhere. And service is not great with a certain disdain in the bars and pretty lousy room service with a 30 minute wait. The main restaurant for breakfast is in the main lobby and is noisy. Not only because it is packed but because the marble foyer reverberates every sound. Get an invite to the executive lounge for breakfast, then expect the same cramped conditions and crowds but with a far smaller choice.The breakfast is pretty broad but is not that good and food getting cold is a problem.The hotel has two tennis courts on the roof but a tiny swimming pool. The gym is pretty good though. No sauna that I could see. The restaurants close at 10pm, except the burger and pasta bar which goes on for another 30 minutes. The Japanese restaurant closes at 9.30pm. Room service after 9.30pm is only for burgers, steaks and pasta. There are no restaurants around the hotel to speak of: it's in the business district. Nor anything else for that matter leaving you with a healthy 12 minute walk to the heart of Shinjuku.If you're planning to arrive by metro at Nishi-Shinjuku then get instructions on the way because there are no signs to the Hilton, although it is quite straightforward once you master things. Hilton could help though.

Hotel is nothing special. I am a diamond member. Told staff I was a diamond member when served in lobby, received no special assistance. Was no special dedicated check in area, had to line up with everyone else. At bfast in restaurant again was no special priority for diamond member had to wait with everyone else. They were offering people to sit in the bar/cigar lounge for bfast cause they were so busy. Who would want to sit in a dirty smelling smoke marinated room. Yuck. Can’t believe you still allow smoking in your hotels. I stayed on a non smoking floor but my sheets still smelt like cigarette. Fruit in the bfast restaurant was all canned fruit from a can. A Hilton hotel can’t provide fresh fruit only canned fruit? Ordered a egg omelette at omelette station. Egg was runny and still uncooked once I got to my table to eat it. Received an upgrade to a suite, carpet had multiple stains. Shower glass was very dirty. Another feature is u can see from the room through a glass partition to bathroom. It’s just covered with a cheap blind. If someone goes bathroom at night it fills room up with light cause blind doesn’t block out the light. Sliding window Japanese style blinds in room are wood and the wood is cracked and broken off around the railings. The lifts in hotel are a joke, so slow, so slow. There are 6 lifts, when u press the button for a lift only one lift lights up to say that that is the lift is coming. So one lift only is dedicated to come get you. What about the other 5? Surely another one could be quicker. Waited over 8 minutes for a lift. The gym are was closed from 8-12 on our check out day so couldn’t use it. No prior notice was given before check in. Hotel is quite far from main Shinjuku. They do provide a shuttle bus but not often enough.Don’t take airport limousine bus from Narita to hotel it takes way too long. Was 2.5 hrs in total. Thanks for the room upgrade, but wouldn’t stay again. I have stayed at better ibis hotels that are better then this hotel.

This is a fantastic hotel, the staff are friendly and helpful, the breakfast is fantastic and the executive lounge offers some amazing views. The quality of the rooms is excellent with a stunning bathroom which offered a great power shower, deep bath with acres of room and the traditional Japanese electric toilet, Bed was comfy and the view was quite spectacular. Position wise it is easy to access all of Tokyo and has some excellent nightlife a mere 20 minutes walk away. My only negative would be the wait at times for the lift, but that is really nitpicking.Stay here, you won't regret it!

We loved our short stay at this centrally located hotel in Nishishinjuku. We used to walk to the metro station using the connecting underground tunnel. Everything is well marked in English. The hotel staff is excellent on every level and we commend them for their service. The food we had in their restaurant was pricey but good. The Club lounge upstairs has excellent views and really good snacks for happy hour as well as a wonderful breakfast of western and japanese dishes. We would stay longer next time if we could.

We are in the middle of an 11 night stay at this great hotel. Good rooms. Excellent serviceAmazing food in the Dynasty and grill restaurants. Also buffet breakfast/ lunch great. Excellent service in the barsA real pleasure to stay here.

Stayed here for three nights as part of a RWC19 tour. It was so nice, the room had a Japanese feel which was very nice and the bathroom was good too. Breakfast was lovely and the 6th floor rooftop bar was great for the rugby, if a little pricey. Would stay there again.

Short summary: The Hilton Tokyo has a great location and provides exceptional service on all levels. Public transportation through nearby Shinjuku station will get you throughout Tokyo with ease. The food options at the hotel are both outstanding in quality and selection. The staff are some of best that Hilton has to offer. Details: I stayed at Hilton Tokyo for a week of work with the desire for visiting some sites. When I suggested a hotel in the Roppongi Hills area, he quickly talked me out of it for many reasons – one was the commute and train congestion in that area and the other was that, in his view, the area was “not so desirable” – he said “you’re diamond with Hilton, why not stay at Hilton Tokyo?” – I didn’t have an answer, other than there was a restaurant I wanted to try in the RH area, clearly I was not thinking straight. My stay at the hotel was exceptional from the minute I walked in the door. The staff are attentive, well spoken in many languages, patient and just overall nice people. Room: I booked a junior suite and was upgraded to an executive one-bedroom suite with views of Mt. Fuji. The room was large, comfortable and well appointed. I appreciated the VERY quiet, very efficient AC system in the room as well as the more-comfortable-than-usual-bed. The views out of the room were fantastic. And there was a Nespresso machine, which was utilized daily.Gym: I utilized the gym a few times during my stay. It is broken out into three areas, plus a pool and tennis court. There is a cardio area, a weight area and another mix cardio/weight area near the pool. The gym was never crowded, and I was always able to utilize all desired equipment during busy times. Restaurants: The ones I visited are located on the 2nd floor, where you will find choices including an outstanding sushi restaurant, a steak house and a Chinese restaurant. I only tried the sushi, which was beyond awesome, and overheard many other hotel guests at the bar (with live music!) just rave about how good their meals were at the other restaurants. The restaurants have an open feel, and it’s almost as if you can mix between them. The space is well designed, open, warm and inviting. Executive Lounge: Simply put, it’s the best at any Hilton property worldwide that I have stayed at. Breakfast options included an omelet bar, various breads and pastries, Japanese options as well as standard English breakfast options. The evening happy hour, which should be called happy-afternoon-evening, was equally well prepared, with options of champagne, red and white wines, a good beer selection as well as any hard alcohols. The food in the evening, as others have stated, can easily be enough for a meal should you choose to stay in for the night. Location: The hotel is an easy walk to Shinjuku station should you miss the shuttle that comes every 20 minutes. There is a pharmacy a couple blocks away should you need to pick something up, as well as the convenience store in the Hiltopia mall under the hotel.

We stayed for seven nights as part of a package for the Rugby World Cup, the location is fantastic and easy to navigate. The rooms we had (1 king and 1 twin) were bigger than expected with good views. All staff we had dealings with were very friendly and were very accommodating. There is a free shuttle bus running every 20 minutes to Shinjuku station, which was great and something we utilised a lot.We had buffet breakfast every day which had a vast selection. We also had the buffet lunch on one day, which again had a vast selection as well drinks and snacks in the bar on level two, where they set up televisions for the rugby which had a great atmosphere and very attentive staff. On the afternoon prior to check out our luggage was organised to be transferred to our next hotel in Kyoto, as we caught the bullet train. During our stay we discovered a 24 hour convenient store in Hiltopia, in the basement, which also had an ATM with English options. Also within a 10 minute walk was a very easy to use laundromat where I was able to do two full loads (wash and dry) for the same price as Hilton charged for two items to be laundered through their service.Overall we had a good experience during our stay here.

The staff was incredibly accommodating to complicated room location request for our large business group. The rugby world cup being in town making that even more difficult for them but they did so without hesitation or complaint.

We stayed here recently in a suite, the room was lovely and spacious. The location was great for getting around Tokyo and the hotel itself had great facilities and was well presented. Staff were always friendly and happy to help out.

Stayed one night before joining a cruise. Chosen because after a long flight from the UK we wanted everything to be perfect. Room, service and food was excellent. Breakfast was very busy but caused us no problems. There was a typhoon overnight but we heard nothing!

Our base for a four night stay in Tokyo. Walking distance to nishi shijiku station, the hotel offers free shuttle buses to Shinjiku station also. The hotel is a drop off and pick uo for the airport limo bus which is a great service. Concierge team helpful with maps, dinner res and airport limo bookings. Large F&B choices of three bars and four dining outlets. The hotel was fully booked when we stayed byt they manage well. Our room was on the 9th floor a king deluxe non smoking. Housekeeping perfect, we made use of same day ldry services. Crabtree and Evelyn Verbena and Lavender toiletries. Water pressure from the shower was incredible and we had a bath tub deep ofuro style. Shoji screens are a nice touch making the room feel japanese as too the in room carpet design with what looks like hiragana writing. Daily free 2 bottles of water. Free WIFI everywhere. TV channels 99% offered in Japanese language. We enjoyed breakfast at the Marble Lounge daily and one day in the adjoining St. Georges bar as overflow due to a mega busy breakfast service.The daily themed lunch buffet at Marble Lounge is hugely popular - you need to cue/book.Zatta Bar on the 2nd floor is great, open until 1am with live music nightly.Overall this was a wonderful choice for our Tokyo stay. Thankyou.

I’ve been here before a year and a half ago, however, this time the environment was totally different. With the World Rugby Championships going on all over Tokyo the hotel us totally booked with rugby fans from all over the world. It’s a little too raucous and crowded for my needs of winding down from two weeks golfing all over Honshu. The breakfast buffet is chaotic. However, the staff has handled it well. I enjoyed my upgraded room. The service is prompt and courteous. No complaints. The real complaint I have is that I booked the room months in advance with points and cash. However, I found out late one night there was a schedule change and I had to change it to arrive a day earlier on the Hilton website, but somehow I carelessly hit the wrong button and ended up having to pay all cash for an exorbitant nightly rate! I discovered my error within an hour when I got an change confirmation. I immediately contacted American Express about the error. I couldn’t get a hold of anyone at Hilton so I called the next AM I spoke to customer service(?). I got a totally indifferent employee that didn’t care about the mistake and repeated over and over in her bored vice that there is nothing that can be done. Totally detached from the problem. I asked for a manager or supervisor. The same old attitude problem. More or less her attitude was “tough S” and it wasn’t fixable no matter what I said or didn’t and that was that. I was told that I could cancel the reservation but either way I would have to pay for it in full. A great option. She said call corporate. So I called “corporate” at the same number. I got the same response from them. Then they said to call the hotel in Tokyo directly and see if they would help. No luck. I was told Hilton Tokyo can’t waiver the cancellation policy and mistakes are not a reason for mitigation. I was told to call Corporate. So it went on in a giant circle in the several hours I tried to talk logic to someone. The booking was weeks ahead and the mistake was brought up timely. Of course Amex was of no assistance. So I accepted it since it was my error to begin with. however, I do resent that the room rate is between double to triple the normal rate! As a courtesy the Hotel staff in Tokyo did upgrade me as a courtesy as a Gold member. My respect for the Hilton has dropped to an extreme low and I will resume bookings with Bonvoy instead. Hilton, you need to re-examine your policies to consider mitigation or relief under certain circumstances. Especially with the timing. I understand that you could loss revenue from cancelled booking etc. this wasn’t a cancellation but an alteration of an existing booking. Hilton, I hope you view this message and can respond to me.

The rooms are clean and modern, the staff was responsive and friendly, and the breakfast was extensive ... and a great way to start a day of exploring. The hotel is also a stop on the Airport Bus and they have a shuttle to and from the Bus/Subway/Train station that can get you around the city inexpensively.

Hilton Tokyo is always consistently the best among the Hilton group. We enjoyed the executive lounge and breakfast. Great service. Great buffet. It is conveniently located in Shinjuku. It also provides a free shuttle service from the hotel to shinjuku station. The airport limousine picks up and drops off passengers directly from/at this hotel.

Our trip was canceled due to the recent typhoon. Despite this uncontrollable natural disaster the hotel staff was inflexible in adjusting our reservation or refunding our money. Further, in discussions with them, they keep changing the "finish line", i.e. what criteria they are asking for to process of refund. Go somewhere else where you are appreciated and valued as a customer.

Those are the three words that best sum up my short stay at the Hilton Tokyo. Convenient location to restaurants, cafes, shops, shopping and public transport. Comfortable bed, fluffy pillows, minimalist design and aesthetically pleasing matched with Evelyn and Crabtree toiletries, what more can you ask for. The buffet breakfast, lunch and dinner spread, selection and quality needs a special mention! Easy to arrive and depart from with the airport limousine bus stopping right at the hotel’s doorstep. Check-in and out process without fuss. Overall, a pleasant stay and no hesitation recommending to others.

good Location just 10 min walk to shinjuko Station, also shuttle bus, large rooms, great breakfast buffet, excellent Service, all stuff very helpful and attentiv, Concierge desk gives all necessary Information about trips and sighseeing, would stay there again being in tokyo, also nice bar and teppanyaki Restaurant at the Hotel, for sure can recommend to stay there, rooms very very clean,

- The breakfast was among the best hotel breakfasts I’ve had. There was an omelette station, a custom noodle soup station, and a wide variety of Asian, European, and American breakfast items. The waitstaff was very attentive. - The room was about what you would expect for a hotel at this level. Maybe it was a bit on the smaller side, but so is everything in Tokyo. - I had a stamped hiking stick from climbing Mt. Fuji but couldn’t visit the Japanese post office to bubble wrap it since it was Respect for the Aged Day. Concierge wrapped it for me, no questions asked (for management, her name sounded like “Kizuna”, she’s really great and what compelled me to leave a review).

We stayed at the Hilton Tokyo for four days. After touring around for ten days in Japan it was really nice to make the Hilton Shinjuku our home for four days. We went to the Zatta bar on the second floor for drinks. All the Staff were very friendly and professional. On our last night, we have decided to have dinner at the Zatta bar, as well as our usual drinks before dinner. Food was excellent and the service was exceptional. One of the staff, Mr Ogawa, was very engaging with all customers from different nationalities and he was very knowledgeable about the Japanese whiskey we ordered. He made our last night in Japan very special by making us feel welcome and comfortable. When we come back to Japan we will definitely stay at the Hilton Shinjuku and hope to see Mr Ogawa again!

They use a Japanese style window; but it doesn't have curtain. In the morning sun light can get through so if you are a "late waker" this may not be a good choice for you. Perhaps they should use a curtain over the window to block the sun light. Breakfast is good with a big selection of choice.Although it's in Shinjuku you may need to walk a long way to the Shinjuku center.Service is good; Too bad the rooms May need a good renovation and design.Air-conditioning is quite weak as well as it's a hot summer night (we already set the temperature to lowest )

This hotel is not really close to many of the attractions that we went to. We also found that there were not really any close places to eat that were not $$$. Forget a view from any window, the hotel is located in a business district. There was a Denny’s nearby but it was not American food. When we were waiting for the bus to the Airport we realized that there was not enough seats or benches in the lobby. The lobby is also very busy compared to other hotels.

This was our third stay at this Hilton property, and it is our favorite of all the Hilton properties we have stayed at. The staff here are all efficient and helpful. We had a small problem, but it was corrected (and then some) immediately. Problems can never be avoided. It is how they are handled that matters. And this Hilton, and especially the Concierge department, really knows how to handle problems properly. The hotel always smells wonderful as soon as you enter the lobby. Everything is clean. The rooms are beautiful, and larger than most hotel rooms in Japan.All the staff members are highly professional, well-trained, helpful, and fluent in English.

The hotel is located just around the corner from super busy Shinjuku station and guest can take free shuttle bus - every 20mins interval from bus stop number 21 near Keio department store. It is also connected via underground passage to Tochomae station (Oedo Line) and Nishi Shinjuku station (marunouchi Line).On check in, Yoshiki-san notice the special comment made on making reservation and upgraded to a Junior Suite on the highest floor which means the view is terriffic!Service was also very efficient that birthday amenities received as you enter the room. Housekeeping is fantastic and keeping the room spotless and well maintained. I accessed the executive lounge and it was packed on meal service, but overall service was quick and efficient. Breakfast has loads selection of both Japanese and western and nice offerings of fruit shots for your morning boost.Best kept secret: this hotel is located just next door to Tokyo Metropolitan Government building which has free access to observatory from its top floors. I enjoyed the time there and would definitely recommend to others.

I just checked in at Hilton Tokyo. I stay at Hilton Tokyo few time a year for past several years. It is very busy hotel. Each time my experience is going down. This time I arrived just past 3 p.m., as a Diamond I went to the Execcutive Lounge for check in and I was finally got checked in and got room around 4 p.m. Do people checking in the front desk at 1st fl. take this long to check-in?My stay is two days, the original reservation was for one night but I could not extend to two nights because original booking was non-refunbdable. I called Hilton Tokyo to make second night reservation and told i want the same room type for second night. But at check in I fouund out the reservation was not so.After waiting for more than 40 min. I was told I was given Execcutive Room. But I was given 14th fl. room with not updated room. Another guy got checked in at the Exxecurive Lounge at the same time got 14th fl. room also and he told me that he also was told that was given Executive Room.I confirmed that the room was not Executive Room. My gripe is that I was not told truth, that bother me. When I inquired seems like they do not care about that discrepency.Again, this is not my first time staying at Hilton Tokyo and on my previous stay I had situation which did not came cross in positive way. Each time I stay, my experience here is going down.

The hotel is lovely, we had an exec room so access to the exec lounge for breakfast, beer and soft drinks all day and cocktail hour between 6&8pm. Good selection of drinks as you would expect and nice nibbles. They have a brand new lounge which they only use for breakfast and cocktail hour, it's so much quieter than the main lounge, really comfy and feels a little bit more exclusive. The staff throughout the hotel are exceptionally helpful and friendly. The room was a really good size, our room was on the top floor so a great view over Shinjuku. The hotel is directly linked to Nishi-Shinjuku station via subway making it really easy to get around. The main restaurant for breakfast was extremely busy and at times tables were a little slow to be cleared, but that was the only tiny gripe I had during my stay. Gorgeous kimonos instead of the usual towelling gowns in the room too.

Staying here now, as is usually always the case with the Hilton portfolio, this hotel is top notch. Staff super helpful & Friendly. The executive lounge is excellent, a great range of snacks & non-alcoholic drinks through the day with cocktails and a generous food (canapé style) buffet offered after 5:30pm.Returned to our room to find a plate of complimentary local cakes, it’s the little things that matter!Great location right across from the station. Plenty of shops & restaurants near by.

Be sure to ask for Ernesto he was so incredibly helpful to us when we checked in! This is one of the nicest Hilton properties i've stayed at and i would love to return. The breakfast was wonderful and the rooms were very comfy and top notch.

We booked the Jr Executive Suite which had a lot of room for wife and I and with our son on a cot. The room was very clean and with a comfortable bed, this is one of the better Hiltons I have stayed at. The room came with executive lounge access, although as a Diamond I would have had access anyway. The lounge is on the 37th floor and has lots of room, food and drinks were great every night, but they close promptly nightly at 9 pm, cocktails only from 6-8 pm, I wish they stayed open till 10 pm or at least have 24hr access for water, etc. As a room option, you could also have breakfast downstairs in the Marble Lounge which had an awesome buffet with multiple food stations, I felt like I was at a Las Vegas hotel food buffet. We also ate at Junisoh the Japanese restaurant on the second floor along with other restaurants and cocktail lounge with live music. The room was cleaned daily and maid service was great! They also left new water bottles every day, neatly cleaned the room and always left adequate supplies of soaps/shampoos/bath wash etc. Concierges were very helpful with restaurant picks, reservations, etc. The hotel is also in a great location, it’s only about a 10-15 min walk to the Shinjuku Train Station or you could take the Hilton shuttle that comes every 20 min or there’s always taxis waiting outside. Or a short walk to the Nishi-Shinjuku station, stairs to the station are right outside the hotel door or inside and transfer to where you need to go. From the Shinjuku Station (world’s largest) it was very easy to go almost anywhere in Tokyo. I highly recommend getting a Suica card which is a rechargeable electronic money card that you can use for trains and purchase items in the station and accepted at various stores. You can purchase the cards at Shinjuku Station.Overall we enjoyed our stay at the Hilton Tokyo and would definitely return for another stay. Service here is one of the best!

Stayed at Hilton Tokyo for a week highly recommended amazing and modern hotel with good sized rooms all staff speak English and professional Yui and Ernesto at reception were wonderful keep up the great work guys and hope to see you soon

Not bad hotel. Had issues both here and at Osaka Hilton where they put me in a room right at the end of the floor on both occasions near the cleaners room. Meaning it was noisy and way too far to walk to elevators. Also at Hilton Tokyo once paid bill they just left me there waiting for a taxi. It’s a five star hotel, they should have the concierge help. When the taxi arrived he expected me to put my big bag in his taxi myself. No help offered. Japan it’s been wonderful but I have to say I can’t wait to get home And I won’t be trying the Hilton again. 5 stars means 3 stars.

Very nice hotel incredibly convenient to Shinjuku subway station with a complimentary shuttle to Shinjuku train station. Very nice rooms with 3 restaurants (Chinese, Japanese, and Grill) on the second floor. The Grill has an exceptional steak for 2 or 3 (Salt and something) that I highly recommend.Several things nearby (Tokyo Governement building with great views across the street), Ippudo restaurant (good ramen), and easy to wander about Shinjuku from there. Nice park nearby as well.Rooms are spacious and well appointed.

Local to all the fun in the Red Light zone, and a short walk to both metros. This is a great location, and as a Hilton member, the only place to stay. There is a mall in the basement with a convenience store, restaurants, a health club and more. Rooms were fabulous.

Normal Hilton standard with some tasteful Japanese touches to the decor. Location is walking distance to the main Shinjuku area and free shuttle is also available to the Shinjuku Station. Dining options are plentiful whether you’re looking for modern Japanese, chain restaurants or to eat like a local at unique standalone restaurants. Price is a bit steep but it’s Tokyo after all.

Make no mistake: this is a large American chain hotel designed for American tastes. That said, this hotel is not just a beige chain hotel. The service is uniformly excellent. The rooms are quiet and tasteful with nice Japanese touches like a soaking tub next to the shower, and shoji screens over the windows. The downstairs St Georges bar has a great vibe, serving a wide range of drinks and with live entertainment. The Japanese restaurant Junisoh is very good.The best part of the hotel is its location, in the quieter skyscraper district of Shinjuku but just a short walk from the bustling shopping and nightlife areas, Shinjuku Station and the lovely Shinjuku Gyoen national garden.This was our first visit to Tokyo and we found this a perfect base for exploring.

The Tokyo Hilton is the only place we stay in Tokyo. It is extremely clean, very comfortable, and the design of the rooms is tastefully modern. But, it is the staff that make this hotel our Tokyo Home. Each and every one willingly go above and beyond to make your stay enjoyable.

Want to start off by saying giving a 4 star to a hotel is not a insult to the hotel at all. I think that way to many hotels are ratted 5 stars this hotel is a great hotel with amazing service my jr suite was so spacious and nice especially for the price you are paying relative to other hotel. The reason why I am not giving it a 5 star hotel is the decor is nice but not fancy like a real 5 star hotel (that why the prices are like that) also even in my the suite the bathroom/shower were very disappointing the bathroom was tiny and the shower felt like you were standing in the bathroom which was not very enjoyable to take a shower. But overall great hotel nice clean rooms great service great location would definitely recommend to a friend on a smaller budget not looking to pay 5star prices

We just returned from 3 nights stay and happy with the hotel. Many exceptional amenities but need few updates as well. Frequent shuttle services 3 per hr to Shinjuku station, large updated breakfast area with wide food selection , gym access are the key things we liked. However I am not a fan of the decor in the room ,also bath rooms were much smaller compared to other Hilton properties we stayed. Also the food selection in the executive lounge is minimal and perhaps it was not worth the upgrade price we payed for the room / lounge access

Review off the Hilton at Shinjuku two salient things I’d like to mention about this visit 1 I have a digital key which I used for the first time the digital key for the room works fine you have to have the Bluetooth on on your phone to use it but the for the elevator it takes at least two times every time to activate that requires at least 30 seconds to 1 minute while you’re standing in the lift in the meantime other people are coming in pressing her buttons with the card and you can go up and down out of sequence till your hearts content so I guess some more thinking to do on the digital keythe second part is the lack of outdoor swimming pool I feel the tennis court could be better used as an outdoor swimming pool it probably gets no more than four people at any one time and they would get a lot more people around a pool and be more attractive for people who want to stay here increasing the occupancy rate

Fantastic hotel in excellent location close to all Shinjuku hotspots. Shuttle service from hotel to Shinjuku station a huge plus. Incredible helpful staff and great breakfast and executive lounge spread.

We stayed at the Hilton Tokyo Shinjuku last September for 5 nights.It is true that the hotel is always very busy in the lobby area, but that seems to be due to the exceptional restaurant located there, which is also where breakfast is served.While we were there they were also having a special seasonal dessert setting that was very popular and looked exceptional, though we didn’t partake.The breakfast choices at this hotel were some of the best I’ve seen with hot main dishes, a dedicated juice bar, self-serve espresso, cold choices, Asian breakfast choices and a bread/pastry area. It gets very crowded here too, but we never waited more than a few minutes to be seated and the servers were very kind and attentive.I was concerned that the hotel may feel a bit out of the way from the main part of Shinjuku, and it was. However, this was not a problem as there is a stairway that connects the hotel to an underground subway, which connects to nishishinjuku station in about a 2 minute walk, and also connects to both the area around the Hyatt in one direction and to Shinjuku station proper in the other, which turned out not to be more than a 10 minute walk at a medium pace. The hotel does have a shuttle, but we felt no necessity to use it.There is also a conbini in the immediate Subway area for quick snack, sandwiches, etc., and a place for coffee, which wasn’t needed, due to the breakfast espresso choices being so good at the hotel.We were fortunate to also be offered a one time complementary sitting at the Japanese restaurant for Kaiseki breakfast one morning during our stay. It was also exceptional, and was located in a very modern, pretty restaurant on their mezzanine level, where we sat at the bar.We booked a standard room, but as gold members at the time, they were able to offer us an upgrade after the first night, to a slightly higher class room on the club level floor. It had a pretty view of the Shinjuku area and its neon, and was decorated nicely, with the paper window covering serving as a shield from both light and noise.We were also offered lounge access, of course, which is always astoundingly good in Asian countries. We had a choice to eat breakfast there, but chose to eat downstairs instead, for the full list of breakfast choices.There was an afternoon tea which had very nice cakes, cookies and puddings, and the beer choices from the evening lounge services were also available at this part of the day, and of course a full spread of evening hors d’ouvres which were expansive enough to make a meal out of, with many alcohol choices, ranging from various hard alcohols to an Australian version of Chandon champagne, which was our favorite.They have a overflow lounge for busy periods which is smaller and more exclusive and quiet. They reserve this for diamond members first, but depending on their client demographic at the time, you may be invited here. We were lucky enough to be given a key to this lounge on our third night, and got to experience this more exclusive service for the rest of our stay. The food and beverage offerings were the same but the service was more personalized, and the space lovely, elegant and quiet.Check-in was quick and efficient despite arriving at a busy time, and expediting our move to an upgraded room was handled with ease. We did check-out through the lounge which was also quick and efficient, with the usual friendly staff.We are looking forward to staying again at this hotel in December when we return as Diamond guests over New Years!

Great Hotel, Great Staff this hotel is the perfect example for the home away from home.The staff is very respectful, helpful and friendly and pays attention to details.This is how all hotels should be.

We had a 4 night stay here recently and just had a wonderful experience. All the staff we encountered were so friendly and helpful and just made you feel at home. An added bonus for us was that upon checking in we were upgraded to a king suite room. What a bonus. Spacious and comfortable with great facilities. The one exception was the bathroom was quite small with too little bench space.Breakfast every morning was fantastic with a great selection of food to satisfy everone’s taste. St George’s Bar on the lobby floor was a great place to sit back and relax, the decor harking back to more elegant times. Zatta’s bar was also good, although with a more modern vibe.The hotel is located in the Shinjuku business area about 1 kilometre from the busy Shinjuku station. So it was easy to walk there, take the complimentary shuttle bus or go to one of the 2 nearby metro subway stations via an underground walkway. Such easy access to Tokyo’s amazing and efficient train system.A great place to stay.

The Hilton Tokyo is in a prime location. It’s above Nishi-Shinjuku Metro Station, which makes it a great base for exploring around Tokyo.The service is friendly and helpful without being obsequious. It’s a super busy hotel, and the staff easily manage the flow of people, which is admirable.The breakfast buffet is next level! It’s not cheap, but the variety is insane, and everything was delicious. They also have clear allergy labeling and were able to provide gluten free bread in request. (Oh and a special shout out goes to the room service chef who made me a very nice gluten free, late night dinner after I’d spent a very long day of trekking across the city.)Our room was spacious, well appointed and easily met the Hilton standard. Our bathroom was clean and comfortable, but a little dated. We were offered a paid upgrade (several times, by email and in person) to a room with a renovated bathroom, but they wanted an extra $700 AUD for it which was excessive. I have only two small suggestions for improvements. The room had nearly a dozen power outlets, but none near the bed which was inconvenient and seems silly. And the price of food is really too high. The restaurants all looked nice, but they are no nicer than any of the other nice places in Shinjuku and surrounds, and there’s no need for the inflated costs.

We have just spent six nights at the Hilton Tokyo as part of a Luxury escape package. Having stayed in many Hilton properties in the past we had high expectations, We were not disappointed. From check-in by Ernesto - upgrade - very good room - great breakfast - fantastic dinners in Juniso Japanese restaurant and Metropolitan Grill, presided over by Niko Martinez who really knows his stuff. Each night at Zatta bar with great music and the beautiful Anna and her smile.The location of the Hilton is perfect. Above Nishi-Shinjiku subway station, beautiful parks nearby, plenty of restaurants within walking distance.Highly recommended.

My wife, 8 month old and I stayed here for a week in August. The hotel is excellent, both in terms of location and amenities. They had by far the biggest rooms we experienced in japan (comfortably fit a baby cot and bags), and the Exec lounge, breakfast buffet, bar, pool and shuttle bus to the major hub of Shinjuku Station were highlights. Staff very helpful and their English was excellent. Will stay there again.

The Hilton Shinjuku is a perfect and central base to explore Tokyo. It's an upscale hotel in what is probably the most central area of Tokyo (Shinjuku). About a 5-10 minute easy walk to Shinjuku station (which gets you anywhere) and close enough to be right near the wild lights, crowds and popular area just north and east of Shinjuku station, without having to sleep in the middle of it. There's also direct access through an underground walkway from the hotel to a subway station which can connect you even quicker to Shinjuku station or anywhere else in Tokyo.Our room was comfortable and with all the amenities one would expect from a Hilton brand hotel, and it had a minimal Japanese styling to it so you get a bit of the feeling of where you're staying,We really lucked out having breakfast buffet included with our stay. Choices were extensive varying from western and Japanese offerings. There’s an omelet bar. The coffee was EXCELLENT and bold tasting. Fresh juices and creative juice mixes are available. Lots of bread options…lots for vegetarians. We’ve seen breakfast buffets at hotels all over the world, and outside of Las Vegas where buffets are at a whole other level, this was the best we’ve experienced. You could set yourself up with a completely different meal every day. The staff was attentive. Chefs were on hand to answer questions about ingredients and the dining area was comfortable, and although always highly populated, never felt over crowded. If you’re staying here, it’s well worth making sure the breakfast buffet is part of your deal.If we were able to return to Tokyo we wouldn't hesitate to stay here. It was a perfect base in every way to explore Tokyo.

The hotel is impressive, but at same time the service not the bestMost of the hotel staff members do not speak English, and it makes difficult the usual communication Executive lounge overcrowded and food selection always the same.I would expect more for such an expensive property Disappointed

Good room and good location. Regular bus to the Shinjuku train station and main district. Only a 10 minute walk as well. Staff are exceptional and WiFi is excellent. The lounge on level 2 is quite expensive for drinks.

Positive points: Good location, metro inside, super nice breakfast, To improve: gym facilities, super expensive barSmall room but for tokyo sense of space it is quite ok.Staff is very professional, perfect english and super helpful

Stay was okay, gym need renovation and better equipment. Room is clean, but some lights were broken. Lobby washroom was extremely dirty, cleaned up afterwards. Executive lounge is very expensive if not Diamond member.

We stayed here as tourists, though it is more of a business tower in a fairly bland area. For us, it worked out well. This was our first stop in Japan and our boys enjoyed having a gym and pool. Our other accommodations did not offer this. You have a short walk to Shinjuku station and dinner areas beyond, or you can take the free shuttle. Convenient location if you continue on to Hakone on the Romance train. Breakfast was exhorbitantly expensive, but very lavish, so pay in advance for that if you think you want it.

Before this stay, we visited Kamikochi and the bell desk kept and stored our luggage for free of charge. It was very useful for foreign visitors and made our trip more comfort and convenient. We got a premium room, it was equipped with a blu-ray disc player, we can enjoyed our owned media.

Our family thoroughly enjoyed our stay here in an executive suite for us and our two children, ages 10 and 15. We were at the hotel for over a week and found it met and exceeded our expectations. WiFi was perfect! Our two children loved room service every day. Staff arranged visits to Hakone and Mount Fuji as well as a private car for airport transportation. Food and drinks in the executive lounge were very good, especially breakfast. We highly recommend this hotel and will definitely repeat when we return to Tokyo.

I highly recommended staying Tokyo Hilton. Had a wonderful time staying for 4 days trip.Excellent location and friendly staff. This was my fourth visit to Tokyo Hilton. Each visit, I experienced their service improvement

The hotel is wonderful. We very much enjoyed our week long stay. Our room was large, and had a lovely view on the cityscape. The bathroom had a large shower room which contained a shower and bath. My husband and I have travelled a lot and had never seen such a shower room. It was pure genius. We really liked it. The breakfast was incredible. The lounge breakfast is nice, but the variety offered at the downstairs breakfast could not be surpassed. We also had the buffet dinner downstairs and that was amazing. The food is high quality, and there is much of it. We through the Hilton members lounge had a beautiful view, and we really enjoyed the drinks on offer during the happy hour. Overall, a fantastic hotel. We would stay here again.

We booked direct with the hotel for 5 nights in an Executive King room including breakfast from 6th June 2019. We took a taxi from Shinjuku station which cost Y970, we felt the lack of service as soon as we pulled up as there was no one to assist with your luggage. Check in was quick, we were allocated room 2829 on the 28th floor. It was a nice room, large comfortable bed, a fridge which you can use and a large shower cubicle, however you wouldn’t be able to use the bath and shower at the same time (unless the person in the bath wants a shower at the same time!), the rest of the bathroom is quite small and there is a metal edge to the bathroom floor where it joins to the carpet, this would hurt your feet when you walked on it. Breakfast was included in our rate, was very good, however it is very busy and found it noisy at times. Gluten free bread was available on request and the food items all had allergy labels which is great to see. Breakfast starts at 0630, however the day we were leaving we ate in the executive lounge as it opens at 0600, however the options here are a lot less compared to the main area. 2 bottles of complimentary water were given each day and the hotel offers a complimentary shuttle to Shinjuku Station every 20 minutes (we only used this once as the underground station is opposite the hotel). We found the location easily accessible due to the underground system (there is a 7/11 and Supermart in the station) but found the service slightly lacking, maybe because it is such a large city hotel that they are just not able to give that fine attention to detail that others can. Overall it did not detract from our stay but it didn’t have the same feel as our stay in the Westin Osaka previous to this.

Came back here after a gap of several years - and although there had been some changes, eg the restaurants - the service and efficiency was as I remembered. The room was very comfortable and the stay was as good as it could have been.

Great location and not too busy to catch public transportation especially if you have JR Pass.We always enjoy having breakfast here and always getting room upgraded as being Diamond member.Mr. Waki was very friendly staff to make sure we had very things we needed during breakfast at executive lounge which made us even more comfortable staying at this property.This past April and at this time, we stopped by concierge desk but both times, staffs were not friendly and being helpful. We ended up getting information from executive lounge staffs.Being friendly and helpful should be concierge responsibility to all visitors around the world.Bell men and women were more friendlier than concierge men. I would say do not bother stopping by at concierge desk, use google which gives you more information.They have complementary shuttles from Shinjuku station to hotel until 9:40pm and airport buses stop by at the hotel which makes very convince.When weather is nice, you can see Mt. Fuji from upper floor’s room.

Many thanks to the staff at this hotel for being more communicative and informative than American Airlines during an unscheduled overnight stop during my flight from Hong Kong to Dallas, TX. Staff went out of their way to be helpful.

Polite and helpful staff. Upgraded to junior suite as a Hilton Diamond. Comfortable large room (remember it’s in the heart of Tokyo!). Enjoyed the club lounge and breakfast with a lot of selections. Crabtree amenities. There are a lot of guests but everything is in good order and the service speed is wonderful. I would recommend if you are visiting the area.

Ok, the view was fabulous, but the room was a shoe box. The executive lounge was lovely, but the food was just ok and maybe not worth the upgrade. The service, I would say, would be 4.5 star. Close, but no cigar.I would try other spots in the same area.

Very, very busy, western style hotel.Check in was quick and easy.Close to Shinjuku station (about 10 min walk)The location was business district so corporate area. You could have been in any western city. Although much cleaner.When we checked in, the afternnoon Dessert Buffet was open in the lobby restaurant. There were lots of people lining up. It was very popular . We were hungry and wanted some lunch so decided to hit the Shinjuku station area for many many places to eat. it did not disappoint.The room was clean and spacious. Great view!My boys went for a swim in the indoor pool. You need to wear a swimming cap.I probably wouldn't stay in this hotel when I go back to Tokyo as its too western and I don't feel like I'm in Japan. It would suit business people passing through.

Nice business hotel within walking distance from Shinjuku station, although the hotel provides a complimentary shuttle from the West entrance of the station. Another convenient aspect is the availability of an airport bus from Narita airport to the hotel entrance. I stayed at this hotel for five nights on the club floor using my HGVC points and the stay was fabulous

Loved the hotel and its location. I would recommend booking your room with the breakfast buffet. It's extra but worth it, There is subway access below the hotel. And the airport limousine stops at the Hilton for easy acces to the airport.

At check-in, the front desk kindly upgraded me to a room on the Executive Floor with a beautiful view, but it was a smaller room in the same category. When I asked if a larger room might be available, they diligently investigated, and offered a higher room category with a small upgrade fee, which was on a lower floor but much more spacious and still with a wonderful view. Also, they noted my allergy to feathers and down, and Housekeeping came to de-feather the new room promptly. Certainly, Japan is a culture without the need for tipping or gratuities, but still, it is tremendously gratifying when all of the staff do their jobs with such professionalism, efficiency, attention to detail, willingness to please, and gracious attitudes. Thank you for another wonderful stay at the Tokyo Hilton!!

Great location. This is a very nice property. They offer a free shuttle to Shinjuku station. Walking distanse to the restaurants. I am very happy with this hotel. The bus service to the Haneda Airport.

Nice comfortable hotel bang in the city center with multiple shopping spots nearby.Food is good with a multiple specialty cuisine options. For Indian travelers who want Indian food there is a restaurant in the basement as well as in the near vicinity also.

I booked 3 rooms since we had family visiting and wanted the “best” for our vacation. As a diamond member, they were unable to upgrade my room due to non availability so they gave all my guest Executive Lounge access-great right? Well the good news ends there. I was underwhelm when I entered my room. I draw a bath and came back to see mold along the grout around the tub...so I just drained it. The walls and the roof are so thin that I was unable to sleep because the room above felt like stomping till the early morning. My guest and I had the breakfast buffet, which was very good. Shortly after we all decided to move since apparently this 5 star hotel did not live up to my expectation. We are now at Hilton Odaiba where we are all enjoying the comfort and cleanliness of this hotel. This hotel has an amazing location...but that’s about the end.

They charged me $403 per night and $100 plus international call that didn’t go through Management very RUDEI will not never stay there again I finall bill amount almost $2,000 I only asked to not be charged weekend rate for the weekday rate

We had a fine experience during our three-day stay. It is a very busy hotel but the staff is top-notch and very focused on providing excellent service. The location is great -- between two subway stations, not far from Shinjuku rail Station (busiest in the world), in a area with many dining choices, and connected via a shuttle bus to the Shinjuku shopping district. Our room was on a high floor with a terrific view. The room decor is Japanese minimalist modern. Only downsides: very crowded restaurants, pricey room rate.

The check-in service was good, no need to wait too long. The staff was friendly and willing to help. The breakfast was good enough but the choices were limited. Same type of food everyday.The room was clean and comfortable. The space is larger than many hotels in Tokyo.I recommended to stay in this Hotel again.

Customer service, breakfast, dinner, and proximity to all modes of transportation... top shelf! Extremely clean and safe... I’ll be back! Staff is very friendly, patient, and fluent in English... making my stay comfortable... thank you

Stayed on 12 hours in this hotel for meeting. The room was good size and welcoming decor and very clean. Good size shower. Pajamas provided and the staff were very helpful for check in and answering questions about transfers. Good position for main station quite close by and shopping. Breakfast selection moderate size but nice. I wished I could have stayed longer.

EntryBell and valet staff are super friendly and helpful.Front DeskStaff at front desk were very nice. Biggest challenge was the afternoon check in crush. Took 20-30 minutes to check in. I think some people were holding up staff by asking travel questions that should have been moved to another counter. But check in took way too long. They need to check in people faster.LobbyThe lobby is nice, but not grand. There are several (very expensive) restaurants, but no where really to sit. So groups are standing around filling all the free space.RestaurantsThe only place we could find to eat after a long day was a hotel restaurant that changed 3200 yen for a burger. That is excessive by any standard. We walked five minutes down the block.MetroThere is a metro stop two minutes away. It's easy to navigate the train system from there. Go to the touch screen kiosk and plug in special tickets. There you will find a 24 hour unlimited tourist ticket for about 5000 yen (children are less). It won't get you on all the trains, but you can go on all the Metro trains free. Caveat is that it's only for the date purchased and not really 24 hours.RoomsVery nice. The size was of a western style room with modern amenitiesHHonorsWe were greeted and upgraded. Turns out we could have checked in at 37 concierge level so check your status -- that could save you time. We also had free access to that level.LoungeExcellent. Great views. Fairly large although it gets crowded from 730-830 (business) and 930-1030 (tourists). They have several offerings throughout the day (although I wish they stayed open later). Breakfast was excellent with lots of options including an omelet station.LiftsThey are maddening. People hit the up and down buttons which causes the lifts to slow down. During peak hours you might wait 20 minutes or more for an empty lift. We finally went up to 38 and then back down.LocationIt's centrally located in Shinjuku although it's more in the business district than the tourist district. It's about a $20 uber right from Shinjuku station where the Narita Express lands. Or you can take the Metro which is a two minute walk. The Metro is convenient. With the day pass you can get anywhere in the city quickly.TipThe metropolitan government building is a block away and has free access to their observation deck where you can look at views of the city and Mt Fuji on clear days.

This will be my third visit consecutively over the last three years to the Hilton Tokyo and one word sums it all: "Unbelievable!"My family was privileged to be well taken care by the team and all our needs was catered for. They always go the extra mile to assist us in all our requests which demonstrates the Japanese standards of service in this hotel. We had a celebration at the hotel and the team led by a very capable management team always makes things happen for us. They supported me in organising the event and offered exceptional suggestions to make it a memorable experience for us. It is always great to be recognised as a valuable guest in any hotel which you are putting up in. The Hilton Tokyo team always gets this correct. They never fail to identify that I have been here before and they are thankful for my support. A few words is all it takes to make your guests feel appreciated and indeed they do this really well.The concierge team has been most helpful and responsive in their efforts to organise my bookings and reservations. They even offered many suggestions which gave us new experiences despite coming back to Tokyo for the third consecutive year. One word describes this team … Awesome! The Junisoh restaurant team went the extra mile to make sure that we had our dinner despite running late for the reservation as we came back from an external venue. We are very grateful and thankful for the team to help us organised with the dinner selection and gave us the opportunity to enjoy the Japanese cuisine and Hilton service. Thank you very much for everything and we thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the Hilton Tokyo once again! :-)

We have 8 people staying for an entire week, which makes it 40+night stay at this hotel, and we booked way ahead of schedule, but most of us got a twin bed room, which was very disappointing. Also, a breakfast was double charged to our friend, and was not solved until a few rounds of investigations. Meeting room was ok, and service is attentive. Breakfast is good with variety of choices, and I would say these gentlemen waiters are quite responsive and willing to help. Room is clean though, and the tennis court is absolutely a plus for me!

My husband and I arrived early from Australia, 6am to be exact and the lovely Monica treated us to breakfast at the best buffet ever. We were allowed an early checkin at 11am which made our jetlag more manageable!The location of the Hilton is excellent, underground access to the Nishi-Shinjuku Metro Station makes travelling around Tokyo super easy.Only one thing we had an issue with whilst staying here was the hugely exorbitant pricing of food. We had an early train to Nagoya one morning and my husband ordered one breakfast to share with two coffees (another extra by accident)- this cost us $100AUD in total for food and drink! When queried, we were told this is just the price- I believe the cappucinos were $16 each. Good stay, high cost, convenience worth it? Probably.

The hotel is big, but didn't feel that way. The service, the rooms, the lounges, restaurant, etc. were great. It was raining so we enjoyed the complimentary umbrellas. It's in a great part of town and near a subway station which was helpful.

Hilton Tokyo certainly came through on a recent family holiday trip to Tokyo. From the warm greetings received at reception, to the thank you's said and celebrated on our departure date which so happened to be the 100th anniversary of Hilton hotels, our 5 nights stay was indeed a comfortable and enjoyable experience. Location was great too being that it is walking distance to the metro subway and rather close proximity to a local garden/park for a nice jog in the morning to start the day.The breakfast buffet in the lobby every morning was especially a treat as it was complimentary for Hilton Honors Diamond members. A good mix of Western and Eastern offerings were on full display. Hence, going downstairs for breakfast is clearly the suggested recommendation over the somewhat limited offerings upstairs in the Executive Lounge. The complimentary shuttle bus service every half-hour to/from the Shinjuku station turnaround was extremely convenient and appreciated, especially during the hot and humid Summer days.For those trying to decide between the Hilton and Hyatt across the street, hands down, the Hilton is the way to go. Though a somewhat older property, the hotel is still nicely appointed and updated to continue to be relevant today in 2019.

Second time here and it did not disappoint. We are diamond members and was upgraded to an excellent room. The Executive lounge and free breakfast buffet was also awesome. Ernesto was very helpful in helping us celebrate our special occasions. Would definitely stay again and recommend this place to all.

This is as American as it can get in Tokyo! It's got large rooms and bathrooms. There are bathrobes and slippers to use. Even if there are two queen beds in our room, we had to get two rooms as a family of 4 (couple & two older teens). Their breakfast buffet is the best with regards to quality of food, variety, and selection. The egg station is amazing since the Chef remembers your order even if the line is so long. It's awesome! The staff is welcoming and professional. This hotel has stores in the basement as well as within walking distance. There are also lots of restaurants within walking distance of the hotel. The Shinjuku station is about a 10 -15 minute walk but there is a complimentary shuttle that is provided every 20 minutes. In true Japanese style, it's on time so if you're even one minute late, you've missed it. It's a Hilton hotel!

Had a great 2 night stay at Hilton Tokyo. Rooms a bit small and a bit dated, however check-in/check-out staff as well as breakfast staff made a big difference and provided excellent customer support. Location is great with direct stop of Airport Limousine Bus. Will stay there again on my next trip to Tokyo.

This hotel is in a wonderful location and really cares about customer service. It specializes in attention to detail. You really can't go wrong here! It was my husbands birthday and I wrote ahead to let them know. They even provided us with a birthday cake. What a great place!!!

Very convenient location. Stress free stay such as choose your room, digital key with your phone and complimentary breakfast for Hhonors Gold members. Internet access was very good. Hotel staff were very nice and professional. We will be back.

I should have known better, progressively of the last many visits to Hilton Shinjuku as a business traveller, I have experienced the decline in customer service, overcrowding in the executive lounge and poor attitude of members of the executive lounge staff. For westerners traveling to Tokyo looking for a decent 5 star experience with executive lounge access, I recommend you look elsewhere. No other way to describe it but very ordinary and very overcrowded and their attitude stinks. I will never stay at this hotel again. Ever.

Extremely disappointed with our stay at the Hilton hotel in Shinjuku.I thought it would be the luxurious end to our honeymoon after staying at another nearby hotel a week earlier...Customer service was appalling.If you are staying on level 36 you will hear noise from the executive lounge above you - they say it closes at 9pm but we were hearing chairs being dragged well after 10.30pm and it will wake you up from about 7am.While we were switched to another room on level 30, the air conditioner sounded like an plane and the walls were paper thin... absolutely loved hearing a baby cry for the rest of my stay and motorbikes on the road 30 floors below...If you eat at the Chinese restaurant - be prepared to pay big money...They say the steak was for 2-3 people but it was not enough for 1! It was literally 8 bite sized pieces for $165AUD and it cost almost $12AUD for 1x soft drink... Not worth the money AT ALL!Oh, how could i forget the bloody bandaid floating in the womens cold bath... I informed staff who simply picked it up with her hand then scooped out 3 small buckets of water that guests use for washing their body. The cold bath was not emptied, disinfected or cleaned...For the money we paid to stay at the Hilton hotel - we were left completely unsatisfied at the end of our honeymoon in Japan.Look elsewhere.

Spent two nights June 12-14 in this fine hotel in Shinjuku. Since we arrived late, I contacted the hotel to notify them of our late arrival, and they acknowledged via email promptly. The hotel is not far from Shinjuku station and is an easy walk even with suitcases. I would advise that one take the airport lime bus since the trains are still packed at 9:30/10:00 pm. Besides the stairs at Shinjuku station are a workout. We were upgraded to a larger room, and it was unique in that there was a glass partition dividing the shower/bath from the bed. And it was controllable from the outside, so fun to mess with people who like their privacy. Japanese toilets are interesting and once you got used to them, they make sense and US should have them.The common areas are very nicely appointed and the breakfast buffet was probably the best I have ever had, variety and freshness. Fitness room is nice but could have used some free weights and a functional trainer station.If I had one gripe it would be the crazy carpet pattern. Could be because we were still tired but swear if made us dizzy ;) Lastly the customer service outstanding. We had a lat flight out and stored our luggage. The manger on duty from England, (awesome young lady) provided us with some tips for the day, and just showed a genuine desire to talk to us about our stay.Without hesitation I would recommend Hilton Tokyo Shinjuku for the rooms, the food, the ambience, and for its prime location to the metro, train, and short walk to the sights of Shinjuku.

The hotel is a good solid hotel - but very large so can get busy. The best thing about this hotel is the location with Shinjuku nearby (10 min walk) or catch the free hotel shuttle bus. The hotel does sell train/subway tickets which is very convenient whilst you get used too using the ticket machines at the train stations. There are 1, 2 or 3 day train ticket passes available for purchase. The train station (Nishi-Shinjuku which is on the M line (no.7 stop) ) can be accessed directly through the hotel (ask for directions if you need too) with Tokyo Station about an 18min trip.Overall this hotel is nice and comfortable and I would stay at this hotel again.

Very close to the Metropolitan bldg where you can go up the tower for free. The spa was really nice. The pool was closed for maintenance when we were there. Gym is small but adjacent to the pool area. You can walk underground all the way to Shinjuku or they have a regular shuttle to the train station. There are also metro stops nearby.

Spent several nights at the Tokyo Hilton. Located in a business area of Tokyo it’s a quick train ride to almost anywhere you want to get it within this very busy city. Rooms are large and clean with incredible views. Though the Red leather chair located in some rooms were probably one of the most uncomfortable ones I’ve ever experienced in a hotel room. Service was fast, friendly and efficient. Though pricing for the restaurants and bars we’re a little over the top. You have other options probably within a block of your hotel which are more in line to which would find it in any other major citys.Overall a very pleasant stay , somewhat generic, but I would also look at other options the next time I’m in Tokyo.

Just returned from a 9 night stay at the Hilton Tokyo and would stay there again.Room/Check-in:Upon check-in we learned they upgraded us to an Executive King Suite and the rollaway I requested for our daughter, was already in the room/setup. Front desk was excellent and rest of check-in was a breeze.Executive Lounge:We used it every day for breakfast (free w/Diamond status) and was never too crowded. My favorites were the daily rotation of different pastries as well as the fresh orange juice. New coffee machines were a bit ‘hit and miss’ whether they would work or not. Hopefully they got the kinks worked out. Staff very pleasant and helpful. Getting around: After taking the Hilton shuttle a couple of times, we found it way easier to walk to Shinjuku station. It is an easy 10-12 minute walk from the Hilton. Overall was very impressed with the service and location.

This is a very nice hotel and once you figure out the right way to go then going to and from the subway station is not a problem and fairly quick. Lounge is very nice and the breakfast buffet is very good also.

Lovely hotel in a great location for dining and entertainment. Our room was on the 35th floor with expansive windows giving a terrific view of the city. There is an entire small city underneath the hotel with everything you can possibly need. Safe area to walk around in. All the rooms have good views.

I will start with the good...rooms were clean and comfortable. We had access to the executive level which was also nice and well run, with a nice breakfast and happy hour snacks and wine/beers. The hotel is located in a great area...very quiet but only steps away from where the action is and train stops. Also there is an airport shuttle that departs from the hotel if you need...which we did so it was very convenient. Staff was also very helpful with dinner reservations and at check in.The only real negative I have is that it is a very busy hotel and there can be a line for check in though the staff was really working hard to move it along. The lobby was loud and always busy. In our room there was only one sink in the bathroom with no separate toilet area. Though overall, we had a wonderful stay at the Hilton and I thought it was a great value!!

This hotel is just fine. The location is great: walking distance to all the things to do in Shinjuku and also offers a free shuttle to Shinjuku station bus terminal, but on a quiet street. The breakfast has a great, large selection, and the gym and pool are nice too. The staff is also very polite and helpful (they translated some things into Japanese for us to help us make some purchases!). But the rooms, and particularly the bathrooms, really need to be renovated. They're clean, but old--the bathroom so much so that it makes it feel kind of yucky. The toilet is also the loudest toilet on the planet. For the price they charge, the rooms should be a lot nicer. The elevators need to be revamped as well, as all of them stop at all 40 floors and are often overfull. (This was the least updated/nice hotel we stayed at on a two-week trip to Japan and Korea, and we stayed at places both more and less expensive.) I am also a Hilton Honors member and was not offered upgraded wifi, or any wifi instructions at all. It's perfectly serviceable, but I wouldn't stay here on a return trip and was disappointed by the room quality for a Hilton.

The Hilton Tokyo conveniently located in Shinjuku has something rather special happening in the way it looks after its guests. Its a busy hotel with a mix of guests, our room was very comfortable and large enough to spread out a bit as you do on holidays. Housekeeping were excellent in their room presentation over the 6 days we were guests and we enjoyed two of the restaurants during the stay, food and service first class. As I have mentioned in previous posts my partner eats gluten free and especially welcomes gluten free bread for toast in the mornings. On the first morning I approached a staff member standing in the lobby saying hello to guests and mentioned about the gluten free bread, the staff member was in fact the General Manager of the hotel Mike Williamson. Yes I know, who knew General Managers of large hotels stand in the lobby and talk to guests. Mike understood my request for gluten free bread and over that day a large number of his team swung into action to assist us. The Marble Lounge Restaurant Manager Mami Yuguchi met with us along with her head chef and went through the steps they were taking while advising all hotel restaurants regarding the gluten free requirement. The hotel sourced gluten free flour and made a number of bread selections - quite simply service above and beyond.
