At the same time Food and Beverage Manager Eiji Kondo kept us informed and made our stay something special. Each morning chef Mr Nobuhiro would search us out with the daily gluten free bread and make sure everything was in order. Now having traveled a fair bit to many cities of the world this level of service from what was at the time a very busy hotel was something special. So if you are travelling I recommend to let the hotel now in advance if you have allergies and what they are. With regard to this Hilton - it looks very well prepared for the coming 2020 Olympics. The Hilton Tokyo is certainly worth your consideration for many reasons - a wonderful high performing team working to ensure your time in Tokyo is memorable - is just the start of it. Thanks Mike and staff.

This was my fourth stay here. This is a nice hotel in a good location - 5 min walk to Shinjuku station but not right in the middle of the noise and chaos. Good executive lounge and breakfast. And overall nice amenities.

My wife and I stayed a total of 6 nights at this hotel. The staff was very helpful, spoke English well, were very respectful and knowledgeable. This hotel is continuously very busy, but they manage to handle the flow of the guests well. It is very clean and well maintained. It is located between 2 subway stations, with underground access to (at least) one, which is nice if the weather is bad. They have a continuous shuttle running to the Shinjuku station - for train/bus transport or shopping. There are numerous lower-cost restaurants close-by if desired. They have regular bus service available to the airports.The rooms were large (for Tokyo) and well appointed. They were clean and comfortable. I recommend this hotel.

On the whole the hotel is very good. I was a bit disappointed about my booking. I did book 3 adults in a single room. When I arrived in the hotel the system did not register as 3 adults. Because of that we haven't allocated the right hotel room. It is allocated to a double bed room instead of 2 double bed room. Hence I have to paid additional single bed fee which I didn't need to another Hilton hotel like Hilton Osaka

I noticed that out of all the Hilton chain I have stayed at in Tokyo (vs. Hilton Tokyo Bay & Hilton Odaiba), I noticed that Hilton Tokyo Nishishinjuku has the lowest understanding of Customer Service. All other hotels' front office staff/manager normally would feedback on any service review emails within 2x24hrs. Yet for Hilton Tokyo, it is already twice that they don't even bother to reply to customers' input, even coming from a Hilton Diamond Member (myself)During my last stay there (May 23rd-25th 2019), the greetings during check-in is one of the worst, and during checkout the billing was done incorrectly (overcharged by ¥67.000 for 2 nights stays). It took over 30 minutes to sort things out as I had to pull out my laptops and open my emails for booking confirmation to show the actual booking rates. No apologies and no feedback even after formal complain through apps and hiltonhonors diamond desks.Well done Hilton Tokyo. And good luck to potential guests, I hope you will not get mistreated and overcharged.

Really enjoyed my stay here. Centrally located close to the business district. Incredible staff - very helpful. Gym and pool were immaculate. Gym staff were so polite and seriously helpful explaining the procedures for entering the changing rooms - changing street shoes etc - all aimed at cleanliness which was very reassuring in terms of standards. Breakfast & lunch in the lobby area was a feast for the eyes and the stomach - everything and anything available - eat to your hearts content. I had two stays here as I had to travel down the country and the hotel held onto my main luggage for a few days which made my travels so much easier. Thank you to everyone for a great stay and especially to the concierge team for exceptional service.

Visited Tokyo for my husbands birthday and it was anazing. Being a Hilton member helped make the trip better because we were able to select rooms and use points during a busy time for the hotel. Price point was a bit high in May but still doable. They set up a great birthday set up for my husband, and made sure our stay was great. I was comunicating with the hotel about a month prior setting up dinner reservations at making sure that everything was what we needed and Hilton Tokyo came through! Room 912 was okay and we didn't have much of a view because it was blocked by buildings and look like more of the back of the hotel , but we didn't mind because we were outside every day that we were there. Thank you for the great service!

I was there during the cherry blossom and you can imagine that how packed the hotel was. Buses of tourists were coming in and out of the lobby. Absolute chaos. My flight was delayed and I arrived the hotel at 3am and there was no concierge service. Hotel room was veryy small for the price paid. Breakfast choices could be improved.

Enjoyable stay. Seamless check in and check out using Hilton Honors app. As mentioned by other reviewers, it was very convenient to have a shuttle to and from Shinjuku Station running every 20 minutes. Walking to Nishi-Shinjuku and Tochomae Station less than 5 minutes. Room slightly smaller than expected but given the area it was understandable. Executive lounge access with gold status vs Marriott with its offerings a nice touch. Near many government buildings with Shinjuku I Tower next door which has a convenience store and many restaurants at B1 level offering outdoor but with smoking dining areas. Overall outstanding experience and very enjoyable stay.

This is Tokyo out the window, so bear that in mind when setting expectations for the Hilton Tokyo. Set in the heart of the government and administrative center of Shinjuku, the Hilton is basically a business hotel. The fact that it is in Shinjuku also makes it an ideal base for tourists. Expect small rooms, but this is not going to be problem unique to the Hilton, this is par for the course for all hotels in the Shinjuku or for that matter Central Tokyo area. The rooms are spotlessly maintained and the beds comfortable and clean. Sleep quality is excellent and the air conditioning is powerful and responsive. Staff are excellent, friendly, and possessed of a comprehensive knowledge of services and area knowledge. The hotel is located right next to to the Tokyo Medical University building and close to several large office towers like the Mitsui building. It’s about a 10-15 minute walk away from Shinjuku station and a 5 min walk away from the Nishi-Shinjuku station which is just round the corner next to the Tokyo Medical University building. Excellent hotel!

What a pleasant place, not cheap - £200 a night and £10 a beer - but very modern and pleasant. Not sure how long ago this was refurbished but it was recently, the breakfast was marvellous, never seen a chef cook an omelette with chop sticks, have now! The gym is pleasant just take your shoes off before entering the changing rooms and wear a swimming hat in the pool. Some Hilton's are a little past their best, this is not the case here, this one is great. Shopping centre in the basement is pointless, rest of the hotel is exceptional. Is 38 floors and the lifts are unbelievably smooth

Great location near multiple train stations. Room was spacious and clean. Staff is friendly and eager to help. Executive lounge serves three meals a day if you have status, it’s a nice option even if just popping in for a cold beverage as needed.

I stayed for 4 nights in a comfortable executive room. The staff are extremely helpful, this really stands out. The gym if well equipped although the pool is slightly small for any real exercise. Tennis on the rooftop would be amazing but I didn’t have time. The downsides are the lifts, which at busy times can result in a long wait, and breakfast in the main restaurant is very busy and one egg station is not enough. I’m not prepared to wait in a queue of 3 or 4 people for an omelette. The location is good, and airport bus shuttle works well if you have enough time (more than 2 hours to Narita).

Short visit however there was no shortage of staff and the they were available to assist with every requirement. I did experience an issue however the staff responded immediately and resolved the issue and did all they could to restore my faith. Breakfast was absolutely amazing, the best choice I’ve seen in Japan so far. Location and shuttle bus is an extra bonus, would recommend this hotel.

If you are tourist then one would be better of staying at Hilton Odaiba, this is a business hotel. We are vegetarians and there are no options. Front desk oversells therefore one has to be on guard. Hope they include more options when we stay again.

We spent 4 nights here and it was a very nice hotel. Easily accessible to tourist sites and public transit. While the hotel was nice, I was surprised it's considered a 5-star property. The overall front desk service was a little haphazard and you would get different answers to basic questions, billing related for example, depending on who you spoke with. Also, the elevator bay has 6 elevators but it was very slow, and often each time an elevator came it would already be full. It was constantly a struggle to get in/out of the hotel, particularly if you're on a lower level floor. The hotel was fine, but if I weren't a Hilton Honors member I don't know that I'd consider staying here again.

We had no clue where to stay in Tokyo - it is such a vast city with so many different areas - so we went with the Hilton, and chose the Tokyo Hilton in Shinjuku. It was a really good choice. It is close to 2 metros and 1 JR station - the busiest in the world.Checking in was quick and our request to upgrade to a junior suite was handled efficiently and at a great price. Our room on the 29th floor had a great view of the many tall buildings located in Shinjuku. The Executive Club was located on the 37th floor and was one of the best I have ever had the pleasure of have access to.The room was very comfortable. Service was exceptional. The breakfast buffet downstairs was one of the best I have ever seen. Every request was efficiently handled with grace and respect.

We stayed here for a week. It’s located at about 13 mins walk from JR Shinjuku station and the hotel offers free shuttle service. This neighbourhood is in close proximity to all the fun and shops in Shinjuku yet it’s in s more quiet area. The room is spacious and clean and it has a very efficient house keeping service - I called and asked for a few bottles of water and they arrived within 5 minutes! The staffs here are friendly and speak good English. It also has a good gym with tennis court and swimming pool. If you want a quiet room but close to Shinjuku, this is a good choice.

Cannot go wrong with this hotel. From checkin to checkout, you will be treated with exceptional hospitality. Convenient location and bonus that they have a free shuttle to the metro. New executive floor is impressive!

Lovely hotel - the rooms are ok, don’t know what I expected from a 5 star but wasn’t totally blown away ! but the view is amazing on the higher floors so should try and get this if you can. The 5 star rating is likely for the facilities which are amazing - pool and sento is a must! Lots of restaurants in the hotel too. Good location about 15mins walk from Shinjuku station, also do a shuttle bus to the station which was great. Area a bit quiet for walking about at night, if looking for busy would move a bit closer to the station. All in all a great stay.

I thought the hotel was quite far fromeverything we wanted to do. It’s also a 45$ cab ride from Tokyo station or 30 minutes on the subway. The 36 floor is so loud from the lounge above you won’t be able to sleep.

The hotel had beautiful rooms which are bigger than your typical Jappanese hotel room. As a Gold or Diamond member, you get free breakfast which is really nice and huge options not to mention delicious. As well, they have an executive lounge on the 37th floor which serves appetizers, beer and wine from 6 to 8pm. It's a nice way to start your evening. The staff is very friendly and always wanting to help. It is pricey but well worth it. It's very close to the centre of Shinjuku and has a subway stop which can be accessed from the hotel. It's an underground tunnel that takes 3 to 4 minutes to get to. Overall, great stay.

We spent 4 nights here on our recent trip to Japan. The hotel was very busy but staff still found time to be very helpful. Our room was spacious and spotlessly clean. The hotel is very well located and close to a metro station or a short walk to Shinjuku.Food prices are expensive but there are plenty of restaurants close to the hotel and a decent coffee shop in the shopping mall under the hotel where we had breakfast a couple of times.

The room of my stay is The Hilton Room,2603，and the experience so far is terrible, the manager told me the online membership sign up has a “opening hour” and the front desk told me “our housekeeping team is off duty” First the problem is the loyalty program, I tried to sign up for the program in the app, but after the data entry page and the select user name page, I did receive a confirmation email, however I couldn’t log in to my account, it keeps telling me “hmm we couldn’t recognise your log in details” So I call the front desk, which couldn’t help but they did give me a phone number which they claim to be a guest service team (I don’t why they didn’t just transfer me), but I called anyway and it ended up to be the concierge number, which obviously couldn’t help, but they did transfer me to the reservation department, which also couldn’t help to figure out why I cannot log in, but they helped me to connect the membership to my reservation and tells me to wait for a few hour for the membership system to update, so I wait.when I come back to the hotel a few hours later, the problem still occur ( and haven’t solved at this point), and I believe it is the duty manger was in the counter, and he tried to help me out but without success, he ended up told me that the service provider is off duty at that time so this problem may need to wait until the service provider is back to duty, which I highly doubt it as I never encounter any online membership registration has “opening time”, and since no one can help, and everyone told me to wait so I keep waiting.But the big part is during my way to the hotel, I learn that the hotel is next to a hospital, and I thought the building under my room is the hospital and since I am travelling alone and I want to avoid my room is facing a hospital.so I approached the front desk to see if it is possible for the room change for a room that is not looking at the hospital , and I was told that I couldn’t change my room because the hotel is fully booked ( which I checked online before approaching the front desk that they are still selling the room that I booked) and they need to keep the room for other guests to check in, and when I say why you can’t just simply swap my room and the non-check room, the front desk call help to her supervisor( I believe he is)Then the guys told me because the housekeeping team is OFF DUTY, so if I change the room no one can make my room for the next guest to check in. WOW I am so amazed by you Hilton, a international 5 star luxury hotel brand that do not have a room attendant after afternoon. Luckily I am work in a hotel and know it is a lie, but how dare you say this lie while you are representing Hilton. At this point I am completely disappointed with the “Hilton standard” which the staff can lie whatever they want to avoid any possible workload. And I questioned his lie of the off duty housekeeping team, he then find me a room at 9/f, although he did warn me that the room view will be so much worse but I don’t care, all I want is not see the hospital, so I gladly accepted the offer and going to my room and packed my luggage. After around 10 mins, the manager helped me with the membership program issue and a bell boy has come, and then the manager come to my room and walk to the window and asked me three time, which hospital, where is the hospital, so I explained my worries to him, he then told me that actually my room is not facing the hospital he then take out his phone and prove it from google map, although I am making the fool out of myself but since this room still making me uncomfortable, so I still want to change my room, but then the manger said the new room that they arranged is facing the hospital and convince me to still in the same room. I am sorry to bring so much trouble because of my own mistake, but this is ridiculous, two of the front desk do not know the view of this series at least they need to know which room will be facing the hospital and even the manger need to come to my room and stand by the window and watch the view and question me three time of the hospital and so then prove it with a google map. Overall I think the front desk had a questionable way to handle requests and I do want a official information to verify if the opening hour of the housekeeping team exists.

Stayed for 2 nights after our trip around Japan. Stayed at the Hyatt Regency at the beginning of our trip (review on tripadvisor) and wanted to try a different hotel.As with many of the big hotels there were no language issues at all, actually no real issues throughout Japan as long as you can learn a few words.Hotel itself is about a 15 minute walk to shinjuku or use the hotel shuttle which takes about 5 mins.We had a club room on the 37th floor with great views over the city, night view was amazing.Usual amenities for this type of hotel and the club lounge was comfortable with cocktail hour 6-8pm. Worth noting that there are two parts to the club lounge, the main bit and the other part which offers slightly less choice, although anything you want from the other part the waiter will gladly get.All staff were excellent and couldn’t be more helpful, they even offered us late check out which was a big help.Overall we would definitely recommend the Hilton.

I checked in late and although the restaurant was closed they offered after hour bites in the lounge on the second floor, and I am so glad I I dined there. There was a live band playing chart topping U.S. songs (both old and new), people were singing along and occasionally standing up and dancing by their seat or near the band, the bartenders were excellent, the after hours small plates were delightfully appetizing, and the overall atmosphere was much like being in a nice lounge in any major city in the USA. A very western vibe in Japan, but it is a western hotel after all. Great place to stay. The breakfast buffet includes Japanese, Thai, Chinese and American cuisines.

We stayed at several Hiltons in Asia in the month of May. This was my least favorite. I interacted with a few front desk staff and at least two of them were very rude and unprofessional. A hotel of this caliber should have 100% of their staff have exceptional customer service skills. On my final night I complained to the night manager and he was very nice and tried to right their wrong. There were some good things about this hotel: the location, the concierges, and the breakfast in the main restaurant. Also kudos to the night manager.

My wife and 14 year old son had a fantastic experience at the Hilton Tokyo. We purchased a Luxury Escapes package which was loaded with value. It included a Junior Suite with Executive Lounge Access including breakfasts with live cooking stations, evening free-flow drinks with premium alcohol, afternoon tea, nightly canapes, free Wi-Fi and private check-in / check-out on the 37th Floor. Arrival to the Hilton was easy from Shinjuku JR station. Walk to KEIO bus station 21 (Shinjuku Sta West) were the Hilton have a free shuttle service departing Shinjuku every 20 mins. You can’t miss the bus as its black and has Hilton decals. Check in was smooth and professional. The Junior Suite room type itself was amazing!! It was huge , around 44m2! More than enough room for 3 people. We were on the 18th floor facing the city, the views have been dearly missed since coming back home! I highly recommend this room type as it gained free access to the Executive Lounge on the 37th Floor. Although access is not essential to having a great experience on your travels, the lounge did come in handy many times. The Executive Lounge gains you private check in/ check out avoiding large lines. You had the choice to eat buffet style bfast at the Executive Lounge or in the main buffet section on the lobby floor. You could access the lounge 24hrs a day. It offered a peaceful quiet setting with parallel dining wings with amazing views out toward the city. It offered free water, beer and juice , tea & coffee. Afternoon Tea every day with small selection of deserts. Selection of alcoholic beverages from 6pm-8pm. An area to kill time and watch the news or surf the net once checked out if your departure is late. All in all very nice perk included in our package. Room keeping did a great job every day. Concierge were friendly and the location was fantastic. One negative was the buffet lunch. It was underwhelming in my opinion due to the cost VS quality of food. Some of the hot food was cold and the waitress said soft drinks were included in the price however were charged on the final bill . I would highly recommend the Hilton Shinjuku to anyone looking to stay in Tokyo.

Sometimes an experience is neither amazing nor disappointing. Sometimes is it perfectly fine. And that was the case at the Tokyo Hilton. First, a couple areas where they went above and beyond. The concierge is amazing. They assisted us with a number of reservations, essential for westerners hoping to dine at good restaurants without paying a service like Pocket Concierge, as reservations are mostly by phone. The spa area is spectacularly. No, it is not technically an onsen because there is no natural spring, but the space is competitive with actual onsens, as the bath area is lovely, the sauna is piping hot, and the staff are attentive. Hard to believe that that it is included at no extra charge.And the lobby and second floor bar/restaurant area are lovely to look at.That being said, the rooms are nothing particularly special. Large desks take up a lot of space in the standard rooms, and the decor is businesslike and drab. They are spacious by Japanese standards and the beds are comfortable, but I did expect something more for the luxury level pricing. Also, there really aren't any other perks for guests. The drinks and food are pricey (though competitive with nearby hotels -- Park Hyatt's are maybe 1.5 the price here). There is no complimentary breakfast and the breakfast buffet is very expensive, and there is no courtesy shuttle. The hotel limo service that offers transport to the hotels in the area is also expensive.Finally, this has no bearing on the review, but it should be mentioned that while other honeymooning guests have gotten upgrades, we didn't get one. I know upgrades aren't always possible given demand, and we did book through Expedia, but since we read reviews that said there were upgrades when we made our hotel decision, it should be mentioned that this isn't customary for every honeymooning couple.In review, the Tokyo Hilton hotel can be looked at as a very fine business hotel or a weak attempt at a luxury hotel. Go in expecting the former and you'll be pleasantly surprised. For true luxury in Shinjuku, I suspect the price of admission will be much higher than the $250/night we paid.

Booked this hotel during my vacation to Tokyo getting away from home during CNY. The great thing about this hotel was that Airport Limousine Bus Service have a direct stop at the hotel plus the hotel offers complementary shuttle bus feeder to Shinjuku Station regularly. There is also a tunnel access to nearby Tokyo Metro.The rooms are quite spacious with lots of spaces for your luggages without cramping the space in the room. The bed can be improved but overall the room are clean and comfy.At the basement, They have a small local convenience store but it’s not 24/7. At the basement there is a local coffee place called “Rie Coffee” and you can order your coffee and they will deliver to the designated smoking area for you to enjoy your morning coffee and smoke. This is really a plus during winter in Tokyo.

Most excellent stay at Shinjuku Hilton! They made our trip very comfortable and convenient. Their staff was awesome and friendly. I recommend their Executive Lounge. They provided a variety of services that made our stay memorable.

Rooms are very large by Japanese standards, well-appointed with great beds and sliding paper screens, and wonderful concierge services. Unfortunately, check-in was slow. I walked right up to the desk and it still took 15-20 minutes for the clerk to find a room. Also, there are several restaurants on site but ALL of them stop serving lunch at 3:00 p.m., so plan your afternoon accordingly. Similarly, ALL dinners end at 10:30 p.m., which is disappointing.

Tokyo Shinjuku Hilton hotel was beautiful, the staff were so friendly and very helpful. To get to the main area of Shinjuku, Hilton offer a bus service, which runs every 20 minutes and is less than a 5 minute drive. For our week there, the Hilton honestly felt like home :)

Repeat stay after 2-3 years absence. Stayed 2 nights. Comfortable bed. Clean room. Basic coffee and tea provided in room. Breakfast is same selection daily, consists of japanese and international selections.

Overall the stay is excellent. We pay around $500 a night for a double. the room is a little smaller than expected. the location is very good. I think its perfect for business travel but not for family with Kids .

Yet another stay at the Hilton Tokyo which is nice and pleasant. I do like predictability and this hotel provides me with familiarity and consistency. I still like the location, view if the room is at the right height, and this time round no issues with sound of lifts.However, it is very crowded during breakfast. Service is standard, not exemplary.Considering the above, it is certainly not the best. But for the amount that we pay for Tokyo standards, it is rather good value in my opinion.

Having spent almost 4 months out the last 18 travelling overseas, shortfalls are very obvious. We mostly stay in high end hotels, yet some of the smaller ones can really teach the big ones a thing or two. This Hilton hotel May impress those who travel infrequently. And it may suit the business person looking for ease, or on a contract.This is a busy hotel. Everything runs like clockwork. Even the egg chef finds it hard to crack a smile whilst flipping his omelettes. Breakfast is basically served in the lobby and it’s a frenzy! Everything you need is there though.This time, because it fitted our itinerary, we booked a Luxury Escapes package. 3 nights, $1300. Non guaranteed early checkin and late check out. Well our flt departs at 10pm tomorrow night and the late check out, after some negotiations, is 2.30pm. Hardly worthwhile. Our room. The remains of the previous guests rubbish behind the rubbish bin is poor but The 2000yen gin and tonic in a test tube size glass with no lemon, and the ‘free drink’ (which was actually part of the package) in the lobby bar that was all ice - very annoying. Hilton has at least now included wifi, as a Hilton member. But in reality they are still catching up with what other hotels offer. Our first two days in the area we stayed in a beautiful 3 star hotel in Narita. To be honest the two hotels do not compare. Everything at the Hilton was available at the 3 star. Service came with a genuine smile and care. The room and amenities were fabulous. Cleanliness amazing. And to top it off, we were given a phone with internet, and free calls (international included) for our use the whole time.My message to retired travellers, do your homework, sometimes you can get better Luxury stays elsewhere.To the Hilton brand - just because we book via an online deal does not mean we do not spend a lot on travel. We spend heaps and we have the time and experience to choose wisely.And for the record, had we known we could not get a checkout around 4 pm we would have been prepared to pay extra!

Thank you Hilton and your great staff for our wonderful experience in Tokyo! A perfect location near two local metro stops, and a free hotel bus drives back and forth to Shinjuku station. There are also many food stores, shops and restaurants nearby.Check-in was quick and efficient. We loved our grand suite, with an amazing view, 3 super comfortable beds and a large couch, fridge and nespresso, free waters, safe, big TV, comfortable bathroom.We loved the executive lounge on one of the top floors, which had great drinks and food most of the day. We also had breakfast there a few days; food is very good and although there are less items than downstairs at the buffet it had some extra delicious items and was obviously less busy. We did enjoy the breakfast in the downstairs restaurant as well, everything was super delicious and a large choice.Wifi worked well. We used the hotel pool as well but found it a bit small.

Hilton Shinjuku has a good location with nice rooms and friendly staff. However, I would never stay here again due to the elevators. One night, i literally waited 25mins for an elevator to arrive that wasn’t full. Unacceptable.

Good location, the subway station is under the hotel. Rooms are not very big but fantastic regarding technology and clean. The executive lounge provides good food but the breakfast is much better in the lobby. And the steakhouse and the other restaurants are fantastic.

Hilton Tokyo is located close to the Shinjuku station and has lots of food and shopping options in the surrounding area. For example, just two blocks away, there's a supermarket "maruetsu" and a pharmacy/beauty store "SEIMS" both open for 24 hours.Free shuttle service between the hotel and the Shinjuku station is very convenient. Hotel staffs were very attentive and overall service was great. The hotel was very busy during the cherry blossom season. As a HH diamond member, we received complimentary breakfast but the breakfast restaurant was very crowded every morning. Also, no room upgrade was offered for us.

Amazing Teppanyaki lunch with Foie Gras, prawns (disturbingly twitched But the chef covered), steak, delicious desert etc etc. One of the best I have ever had. An excellent mango juice too. I discovered the chef was considered a junior as he had only been doing for 10 years! Well worth a visit specifically for lunch

Very friendly staff. Plenty of English spoken by wait staff and guest services personnel. Easy access to Subway and Trains. Shuttle buses available to both airports. Complimentary shuttle to train station. Executive lounge was very crowded for happy hour and for breakfast.

Hilton Tokyo was the last stop of our tour through Japan. Convenient location with its own metro stop & free shuttle bus that ran throughout the day & evening between the Hilton Tokyo hotel & Shinjuku Station. The Executive lounge was being renovated but the breakfast buffet in the lobby had a wonderful selection of food & drinks that we enjoyed every morning. Also enjoyed a delicious kaiseki dinner at Junisoh. Customer service was great during our stay. The premium double bed room was comfortable with great bathrooms with ofuro tubs. I would definitely stay at this hotel again when visiting Tokyo.

Our original room was small so we paid for a suite. This was fine with views of Mt Fuji in the mornings. Meals in the restaurants were excellent although the Teppanyaki is expensive. Staff were all helpful and efficient. The downside was the Executive lounge which seemed to be accessed by everyone in the Hotel. It was so crowded in the evening that we couldn’t eat there and even had to take pre-dinner drinks to our suite. The lounge is useless for business travellers wanting to relax after a day’s work or entertain a client.

Hotel very pleasant,staff friendly,not located very close to large shopping areas, they do offer free shuttle to main area of shopping. Metro connected to hotel,a little walk.Executive lounge just remodeled but very crowded in the evening,get there early or no seating.Breakfast in lounge very good,nice view of Mt. Fuji on a clear day.Rooms modern and views good.Not a five star hotel ,maybe 4.5.

My partner and I have been to Tokyo for more than 10 times either for work conferences or leisure in the last 5 years, so I would say that we know what we wanted in a hotel in this beautiful metropolitan city.This time we traveled during the Easter Long weekend, we caught the overnight flight (red eye flight if you are Aussie) to Tokyo Haneda Airport, arriving at 5am in the morning. We initially did not think to book the extra night, thinking that we could stay up and roam around in the city until the 3pm check in time. One week before we travel, we changed our mind and decided to book an extra night - and Hilton was really helpful and was able to get us a room (during Easter Peak season!)- although the room was at a lower class, but it was a room for us to rest up after our long flights! When we went out for lunch, the staff helped us to move our luggage to our intended room and we barely felt any inconvenience (if any) at all!Furthermore, as we were unable to book Sushi Jiro on our own, we have asked the hotel to help us in advance. With a small fee (3,000 yen) they went to the restaurant in person to help us to secure a reservation, although it didn't work out (it was fully taken by the restaurant's regulars, who have priority over tourists like us), the Hilton staff have given us other michelin star restaurant recommendations and have helped us to secure those bookings as well! We have been to those restaurants and sincerely loved it! Really want to thank them for providing such accommodating services and professionalism. We will continue to go back to Hilton Tokyo for many trips to come.

Spent nine days at the Hilton as a base for exploring Tokyo and the surrounding area. The hotel was superior in all respects! The concierge service was excellent and we came to rely on them for suggestions, directions and general guidance. The complementary buffet breakfasts were incredibly generous, the service was exemplary and the food, whether western style or traditional Japanese, excellent. The room was spacious, clean and had a view of the city. The hotel is located convenient to two different subway lines and there are plenty of 3, 4 or 5 star dining experiences within walking distance. The staff were all excellent. The fitness center clean, spacious and well outfitted. I can't think of a single critical thing to say. I'd definitely stay there again.

Love the property and enjoyed the vacation. Pros: - Great breakfast selection- Decent gym- Spacious room size (for Japanese rooms) - Love the executive lounge- Location near subway - Staff all very helpful and nice Only "bad" thing: - Not much happening in area, it's in nishi-shinjuku, not shinjuku itself

As always, Hilton delivers a superior experience in the heart of Shinjuku. This is perfect for business stays. Great location, great staff and the exec lounge make my trip consistent and productive. Breakfast is quite nice

This Hilton property is right near Shinjuku Station, the busiest train station in the world. The nearby neighborhood varies from business-like with high-rises near the hotel to shopping mall near the station and party and night life area just beyond. From the station, one can get to just about any point in the country. The hotel looks and feels like any American counterpart. My one gripe is that I originally picked out a room only to find out that it was a smoking room when I checked in. I appreciate that the person at the front counter pointed that out and found me something else. The new room was fine. I was offered the change to "upgrade" to a remodeled room after one night. The last room was nicely remodeled, but was actually smaller than the one I had previously.

First visit to Japan my husband and I booked a cruise that included a pre-cruise 3 day stay and land tour. The hotel arranged for our large group to check in on an upper floor in one of the meeting rooms handing out welcome packages and room keys while handling our luggage. We were served buffet breakfast and gathered before tours in a conference room every day until the cruise ship sailed. The mornings were hectic and the elevators were pushed beyond capacity resulting in long waits and grumpy guests. One morning my husband walked from the 24th floor down to the 3rd or 4th floor to the meeting room for our tour. Walking down the stairs wasn’t an appealing option for me since I’m recovering from a broken leg but I considered it when the 3 full elevators stopped and left a growing group of us. Eventually we got on an elevator going up and just rode it up to the 31st floor and then down. It was an inconvenience exacerbated by jet lag. This is the only negative thing I can say about the hotel. The staff was friendly, courteous and helpful even when dealing with frustrated guests. The shuttle bus running from the hotel to the Shinjuku train station was convenient and made getting around so easy. The signage with the schedule and location of pick up was excellent. Breakfast was delicious and I appreciated being able to get eggs made to order as well as pancakes. Our room was comfortable and clean. The views were great. We stored snacks purchased in the convenience store in the arcade in the mini fridge. My husband and I slept well in the comfy bed and quiet surroundings. The tv channel selection left a little to be desired but we were thrilled to be able to watch most of the final round of The Masters golf tournament even narrated in Japanese. Some things just don’t need to be translated.The concierge recommended an excellent restaurant and gave the taxi driver directions. The hotel supplied map was excellent and all we needed to get around on our own when we weren’t on a tour. I would definitely stay here again but I would probably ask if any large groups were in the hotel and adjust my schedule and expectations accordingly. We were there before Golden Week and after the peak of cherry blossoms but the place was busy all the time.

The Hilton Tokyo is great!!!The location is fantastic, the service is spectacular, specially at the breakfast.... Waki, our waiter at the Executive breakfast lounge, was AWESOME!!! He is very kind and goes above and beyond to help.... he also speaks great English!!! Waki definitely made breakfast the highlight of our days in Tokyo.I highly recommend the Hilton Tokyo

During check-in, the front desk was very welcoming and acknowledged my Gold membership, trying their best to upgrade me to an executive room. We ended up getting a room on the highest floor which has been renovated. The room was spacious and bed was comfortable. The lounge was busy as it was golden week but cocktail hour was enjoyable. Breakfast was a very good spread of Japanese and Western options.Thank you for making this an enjoyable stay! Every interaction with the staff was warm and friendly. Appreciate the effort in getting the room upgrade as well. Excellent service all round

Everything about this hotel was great. The concierges were absolutely wonderful. Front desk staff were quick and very helpful both on check in and check out as well as during the stay. The location is fantastic, close to The subway station and there is even a free shuttle bus from the hotel to the main shinjuku station. The rooms are modern, clean and spacious. The buffet breakfast in the morning is enormous, with a vast array of selection. We definitely look forward to returning to this hotel anytime. It is also very close to 24 hr markets and office buildings with restaurants on the first floor. Ippudo Ramen restaurant is in an office building adjacent. Don’t miss it.

Our room on the 10th floor was beautiful. The bathrrom set up was not ideal in my opinion. The shower plus bath tub are in a separate room within the bathroom. You cannot avoid getting water into the bathtub while showering. I felt bad dirtying the bathtub indirectly every time I showered. The executive lounge had just reopened after being closed for serveral months for renovations. I did not like tge lounge set up, as there were two separate lounges and sometimes the food options were different. The staff was very nice and professional but they seemed understaffed/overwhelmed. Perhaps it was due to the hotel being full for Golden Week, but there was lots of laspe in service. For example, the soup spoons and bowls ran out and no one replaced them for 15-20 minutes during evening cocktail time. We put our names on the wait list for lounge use due to the lounge being full and were not called back until an hour later. Also, we did not get any recognition for being Diamond. Other hiltons sent personal emails to welcome us pre-arrival, left us a card in the room, and/or provided a welcome gift. We did not get anything other than one hour later for checkout, and that was because i inquired about it.Convenient location and free shuttle to shinjuku station were appreciated. Pool/fitness staff were very friendly. Pool water was very warm and comfortable!

This is my third stay at Hilton Shinjuku and the first 2 stays were fine. This time however (4-nights stay May 1-5) was not good as the hotel appears to be unable to deal with full occupancy. Hilton Diamond "upgrade" at check-in to a so-called corner room rather than a suite was understandable since this is a busy period, except that the corner room (1829), is not in a corner at all and as far as I can tell is no different from the other rooms on that floor. Housekeeping is not available after 6:00PM (surprising for a hotel of this category) and repeatedly failed to show up when called within their business hours (had to call 3 times today before they finally came). The renovated Executive lounge looks the same as the previous lounge and every single day there was a line to get in. I got seated at the "counter" (i.e. no table available) every night, caught a cold from the aircon that was blasting next to the only place where I was allowed to sit (at some point I moved to an empty table and was politely asked by an attendant to get back to my counter seat, which is unbelievable). Cocktail hour is from 6PM to 8PM. As I came in at 6:40PM tonight I was asked "do you need to be seated?", then "can you wait in your room and we will call you because we are full"? After I explained that the cleaning staff was in my room because they forgot to come earlier and so I could not wait there, a counter a seat magically appeared (next seat remained empty). Overall a very disappointing stay, I hope this is an exception due to the holiday week-end. And whoever renovated the lounge should have thought of a better design, there is just no place to sit while tables for 4 are routinely occupied by single travelers who arrived early. The only positive was the lobby floor's restaurant breakfast staff, who was very nice and efficient.

Okay, it is pricey but this is Tokyo and you get what you pay for. As gold members we were upgraded to a lovely room with executive lounge access. The room had a Japanese feel, with a lovely bathroom with Shoji screens and Yukata to wear. The lounge just reopened and had a lovely view of Fuji San our first visit. Complimentary champagne, hot dishes made a lovely happy hour. Truly enough for dinner, but Tokyo is waiting. They also had a nice afternoon tea with scones. Loved the hot milk for tea. And breakfast there was much nicer than the large buffet with wonderful pastries and cheeses. But most of all it is the service that elevates this hotel. The complimentary shuttle to Shinjuku station runs three times an hour. We had experienced an issue enroute to the hotel and the way it was handled was exemplary. Monica on checkin and the on duty manager completely looked after us. Later we met Yoshi who was outstanding in making arrangements for us. They made our stay truly special. Thank you!

I expected a massive hotel without a lot of luxury or service what a great surprise this was! This recently renovated hotel was amazing! We had a room on the executive floor and it was gorgeous!everything was new and absolutely beautiful. The service was top notch as well. All the service was so professional and polite! It felt like a Ritz Carlton! The executive lounges were amazing and had the most and best food selection I’ve even seen in an executive lounge. I highly recommend hotel and would definitely stay again f ever in Tokyo. I can’t say enough about this hotel!

Lovely experience to stay at the Hilton Tokyo. The location and service is excellent. The new Executive Lounge and staff are first Class. This hotel has everything Japanese hospitality has to offer. No problem recommending it.

We stayed here prior to taking aa Regent Cruise from Tokyo. We had a good sized, quiet room, with a comfortable bed. The staff were helpful,giving us a couple of very good restaurant recommendations. Just a 15 minute walk to Shinjuku station and its surrounding shops. The park opposite was ideal for a fresh air walk.

Convenient to trains, restaurants and the 2020 Olympics.Friendly staffLarge bedrooms compared to most Asian hotelsPark across the streetStarbucks and Denny's with English speaking staff are down the road

Having just one day in this city, this Hilton Hotel was the perfect spot to roost. It felt much more luxurious and stylish than it needed to be! Excellent staff, a warm modern look, and a wonderful bed to sleep. Highly recommend it!

This hotel is a bit off the beat and path. 15-20 min walk from Shinjuku station or you can take M line one stop and transfer. The room and view is cool, but there are no outlets by the bed or USB ports in the rooms. You would expect top notch technology at this price in Tokyo. Service is excellent and gym/sauna area is great. My 5th time in Tokyo, I enjoyed my stay but in the future would stay closer to the bigger stations

two words: BREAKFAST BUFFET. Also, the rooms. Also, the staff. Zero complaints with this stay; only wished we weren't so busy seeing the sights of Tokyo that we had a chance to use the spa! Will return if we have enough points to book it again :)

Outstanding hotel in the Shinjuku area. Nothing is too much trouble for the staff, who go out of the way to accommodate any needs.Great selection of different cuisines, spacious and comfortable rooms, which is unusual in Tokyo. Highly recommend

The hotel is a 30 minute walk to the busy Shinjuku station. For guests who don’t like walking, the hotel has scheduled shuttle service that brings guests to Shinjuku station and back to the hotel. The airport limousine bus also picks up guests from the hotel lobby to the Narita/Haneda Airport. Very convenient!

This very busy hotel is minutes from Shinjuku station and the hotel has complimentary shuttle buses to it. The hotel was completely sold out when we arrived and the check-in representative apologized that I could not be upgraded - which is understandable given the situation we were in. She then proceeded to explain how breakfast and the lounge worked. During my stay, I was able to try the lounge breakfast, breakfast buffet and the special traditional Japanese breakfast. I would encourage everyone to try the Japanese breakfast at least once, but my personal favorite was the breakfast buffet. Overall, a convenient and well run property that I'll likely return to next time I'm in Tokyo.

The location is alright - 15 minutes walk to the main Shinjuku train station. The hotel sit close to different train lines so it’s easy to get around. At night, it gets a bit quiet.The rooms are a bit small but it’s decent. Although the hotel itself needs a bit of a renovation. Compared to the last time I stayed here, the hotels seems busier. The elevator takes a while in the morning as it’s always packed.The executive lounge was closed during my stay but was suppose to be open at the end of the month.

We had a great 5 days stay at the the hotel at the end of the sakura season. The staff were great, friendly, and attentive to our requests. The breakfast buffet was plentiful and delicious, a great way to start a day of sightseeing. The subways are right underneath the hotel, and once you figure out the way, it is very convenient to travel around the city. I recommend you take the limo bus from the airport as it will drop you off right in front of the hotel. We will definitely stay at the hotel again in the future, especially with the newly renovated executive lounge.

The Hilton Tokyo is a fine hotel and we would definitely stay there again. The king bedded room was not large but was ok and, like the hotel in general, was very clean. The hotel is large and so the breakfast buffet was crowded but there was a large staff to handle it and we did not have to wait for a table. The food choices were quite extensive and overall quite good. It was definitely worth it to have had the breakfast included in the room price. The staff was uniformly welcoming and friendly and helpful. Of particular note was the shuttle bus which ran every 20 minutes to and from the Shinjuku train station which provided an easy way to get not only to the train station but to the heart of Shinjuku restaurants and shopping (helpful because it was raining a couple of the days we were there). The walk to that area--about 15 minutes--also was easy. There was access to the Nishishinjuku subway/rail from the hotel too. Overall it was an excellent stay.

I made a reservation with a king bed but was given 2 small beds. I was told that i was upgraded presumably to a deluxe room. The room was anything but deluxe, facing a brick wall looking at absolutely nothing but dark alleys on a lower floor. To make things worst, I went to the executive lounge and as I diamond member I usually get great perks but was told it was closed after 8pm, I showed up at 8:45pm. I asked if I could just get something to drink (just a juice or soda) but was told nope! It's now a bar and if you want a drink you'll have to pay for it! WOW, what service. In all my stays at this location it's the first time I've been disappointed for many reasons. This is not how you retain your most loyal customers. I'm happy to try the Hyatt across the street next time if you don't want my business!

It has the best buffet breakfast with a lot of varietiesvery nice and clean rooms with Crabtree and Evelyn amenitiesvery good servicelocation is ok with free shuttle bus to central Shinjuku every 20 minutes

Great location near a park and metro station. Good shopping and Dining options are walking distance away. Hotel Breakfast is a bit crowded as the club lounge was under renovation. The hotel has 2 sides and one has great views of the park.

The room was large and clean. There was a complimentary shuttle that we took to Shinjuku station. We went to Hakone for a night during our stay and there were no issues with leaving our luggage at the hotel. There was a Starbucks around the corner which was great as there was no coffee machine in the room and the coffee from the hotel restaurant was mediocre. Bottled water was complimentary. There were several food options in the office building beside the hotel. The airport bus to and from Haneda stops at this hotel which was very convenient.

Situated 10 minutes on their shuttle bus it really doesn’t live up to the Hilton name. Hotel food selection was Chinese or Japanese or a version of European with a buffet lunch and dinner which was so overcrowded it was hard to get to the food and get your knives forks or chopsticks. Quality of the food was only okay and we chose to eat out only using the hotel first night and for breakfast. Rooms big and bright and concierge helpful. Get a map it’s hard to go from a to b without either knowing or asking as you walk along and not much English spoken outside the tourist track There are better more central hotels from which you can walk out from your hotel directly into the madness that is Tokyo without having to wait to be taken and collected by shuttle bus. Also use the subway system which is fun and easy

I have been to Hilton Tokyo several times. Location is great and rooms is always clean and cozy. However, I ran into problems with breakfast staffs. Once they put me in a bad corner. This time a staff refused to give me space in a more quiet area. Explanation was blunt with moody manner. This killed the overall rating and I feel bad for other people in the hotel who performed so well.

We have stayed here for several years in a row during the Spring. It is always a wonderful experience! The location, staff, and accommodations are fantastic! We love it here. We recommend it to our friends all the time!

Fantastic service once again! I stayed here once before and this location once again did a great job exceeding expectations. My boyfriend and I were here for Marathon weekend. We had breakfast as part of our package and enjoyed having it every morning. We also liked the access to the subway and the free shuttle to Shinjuku station. We did get lost a few times but always found our way. Check in was smooth as was check out. I was a bit sad being placed in an older room I believe. I talked up the bathroom to my boyfriend and we got to the room and it was just a basic bathtub/shower combo like in America. Other than that this was a fantastic stay and I would recommend this location.

I was recommended to the Hilton as it is relatively close to the start line of the Tokyo Marathon. I did not check out much beyond that .However , I did not expect to be bowlers over by the hotel . They were friendly , efficient and kind . We stayed initially for 5 nights in a newly refurbished room which was terrific . The 2nd stay was one night only on our last night - the room was huge but the bathroom was a little dated but perfectly fine . Their buffet breakfast was one of the best we have ever experienced - a real treat. We discovered, by chance, that there is a metro station that connects directly to the hotel too - its about a 7 minute walk underground from the hotel . The only downer the Executive Club was closed as was being refurbished and their alternative arrangements for snacks in the evenings were very disappointing and not thought out ... but we would definitely stay there again !

we booked through a travel agent. we asked for a king size bed. the itinerary said a twin room. Seem familiar? We thought so but when we arrived we had a pair of single beds. This seems to be a default setting in Japan. I suggest when you book you specify and request confirmation you get a king size bed if you want one. The rooms were small but very well appointed and modern. The breakfast was terrific. Overall a very pleasant experience

I don’t think I’ve ever been in such a busy hotel. The foyer is constantly full of people, the lifts so full you have to wait ages to get into one, the restaurant surrounded with huge queues.However, the bedroom was very comfortable, the facilities around it, shops restaurants were plentiful and the staff were extremely helpful.

A decent hotel located in Shinjuku.Prices tend to be little above expected, but it is the Hilton.Affords easy access to Shinjuku station, within walking distance. Also sited close to the meeting point for the VELTRA tours at the Keio Plaza hotel.Hotel has an extensive room service menu, but seemingly does not have a restaurant that actually offers these foods, hence lunch dinner options are limited to the Chinese restaurant and one other that offers 1 or 2 other dining options-a little beyond what most tourists probably want especially in terms of cost.The lower level dining area does have other dining options, but is more cavern style with some odd combinations of foods?Hotel probably suits business clients better. Otherwise well organised and check in and out was efficient and smooth. Rooms can be a little pricey for the tourist.

The hotel is overall decent and comfortable. The room was comfortable and clean with Japanese architecture infused in the architecture.The staff was generally friendly in exception of a few especially in the coffeehouse. Also, there are many restaurants and coffeehouses in the hotel. Yet, the main coffeehouse at the ground level is always over crowded and their opening and closing times are very confusing as there is no notice of the timings. Also, the staff was very slow in picking up our luggage although we were in a rush to catch our train. The hotel is in Shinjuku which is good because you in a accessible area with lots of good food and attractions nearby. Additionally, the hotel is affordable so it is safe to say that despite the flaws that the hotel has, the hotel is a good value for money.

as we know , Tokyo is very busy cityThis hotel is super busy , even by Tokyo standards, feels crazy.For front desk or any staff you just next in line.Don't get me wrong, they very nice and do as they can, but infrastructure and turnover of this hotelfeels overwhelmed.Really big issue with a lobby, Is very, very bad and feel like hostel.On positive side rooms are beautiful and clean.Like to say HUGE THANK YOU to Ernesto !Thank you Ernesto for all your help during our stay.

This review is for the deluxe room, which is the second lowest room type. They artificially create over 10 types of the rooms so that at their mercy, they can “upgrade” you to next level but in fact you are not. Say if you are a diamond on an award stay, you will be upgraded from tier 10 room to tire 9 room.Some of the obvious bummers of the room. 1. Low ceiling. If you are taller than 6’ you will feel the pressure from top, at hallway and common area.2. Splashing shower water onto bathroom ground.3. Thin wall. Enjoy free TV audio shows from your neighbor.4. Very average amenities. In room instant coffee. Really?Although none of these will ruin your stay but for “high end” hotel with a minimum nightly price over $300, it is hard to accept. Even some lousy airport Hiltons do better than that.On the other hand, services from all staff are impeccable. Free shuttle to Shinjuku station is short but really helps a lot, especially on rainy day with luggage.

As a Hilton diamond member, my adult daughter stayed here on points for 4 nights at the end of March 2019. We had a twin room on the 27th floor overlooking the city. The room was very comfortable and so were the beds. The only thing that I did not like about the room was that the bathroom light shined into the bedroom at night through the privacy glass if one used the bathroom during the night. The executive lounge was being renovated but the hotel more than made up for it and had a delicious breakfast and cocktails and hors d'oeuvres on the 2nd floor. Housekeeping was efficient and quick when I ask for something it was delivered quickly and our room was made up each day before we returned. The bell desk and valet were perfect and helpful. A great tip, have the bell desk send on your large luggage to your next stop if you are taking the train. You bring it down the day before and it only cost $36.00 for 2 suitcases being shipped from Tokyo to Kyoto. I would definitely stay there again.

Outstanding locations coupled with excellent front desk staff. I have no complaints whatsoever because the Hilton Brand never detour from its mission to ensure a memorable stay. The shuttle service was an added plus which eased the burden of our adventure. Thank you Hilton for making our journey a most memorable one.

We were only staying in Tokyo for a few days but the hotel really helped make the trip. The staff were always helpful, perhaps to the point of being overbearing (we received knocks on the door asking if we wanted our room cleaned when we had the do not disturb sign on) but helpful nonetheless. The room itself was immaculate, although the view was not perfect. There are plenty of amazing restaurants available, such as the Metropolitan Grill and a lovely Indian restaurant just downstairs from the hotel lobby. Overall a fantastic place to stay in a wonderful location.

This is an outstanding hotel in an excellent location. The staff are friendly, courteous, and helpful. The only negative was that the executive lounge was closed for rehab during our stay but was replace fairly well by facilities on the second floor.

I'd been here for 4 days in my short bussiness trip.Location is great and convenient as well.The room was comfortable and clean.Bathroom was a little small but acceptable comparing to others hotel in Tokyo.What made me happy was the politeness and helpfulness of their staff.They showed their well- trained attitude.But, the last day i was there, i tried the pool and when i cameback to my room,well ,4 spots appeared on my back!

This particular Hilton location is really solid. Just a few blocks from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (great views, just be prepared for a line), the location is also fantastic. The underground tunnels and rail location this spot are great. Additionally, this Hilton location provides shuttles to the train stations as well, so it's easy to get around. The room was clean and spacious and, like other Japan Hiltons, had a really awesome bathroom with a shower/bathtub combo. As Diamond Club members, we were informed at check-in that the executive lounge was being remodeled. To compensate for it, the hotel instead provided access to a great bar for happy hour and access to the buffet breakfast in the morning for food. The food options were really good, and fresh, however, not as fresh as our stay at Osaka Hilton. This replacement for the executive lounge was awesome. We stayed at a property in Houston where the executive lounge was also undergoing renovations. The Hilton property gave us some soda and bag of chips and thought that was the same. It wasn't. The only downside to this hotel stay was the service. Throughout Japan we had friendly, welcoming service where everyone provided an 11/10. Especially at Osaka Hilton. When we checked into Tokyo Hilton, the staff were all harried and the check in agent was gruff and short with us. He did his job but the difference between the quality of service at Osaka Hilton and Tokyo was huge. That said, it didn't negatively impact the stay, and we would happily stay there again.

We enjoyed our stay at the Hilton Tokyo. One thing we noticed in the lobby is the lack of seating. Perhaps this is due to the the restaurant taking up a rather large portion of the lobby. There are many enough seats for 7 people in the lobby and while everyone is waiting for shuttles, limo busses, etc, there's a lot of people standing around for long periods of time at times. Other than that, the staff are very polite and helpful. I think almost all of them spoke english which was helpful and convenient as english speaking foreigners. The lobby is also very nice in general with a little section with baked goods as well. There is a complimentary shuttle that runs around every 20 mins from the hotel to shinjuku station. If we were planning to take the subway at shinjuku station, we would just go to the subway station below the hotel (M09), which is just one stop after shinjuku station (M08). It cuts down any time you have to wait for the shuttle and it's definitely less busy at the subway under the hotel (I believe it's called Nishi-Shinjuku Station). So depending on our situation, we utilized both the shuttle and the subway under the hotel.There are also a bunch of vegan options at restaurants at Shinjuku station for anyone who needs one, because you won't find any options at the hotel. The rooms were okay, clean and comfortable. The bathroom was a little awkward in that it was small and if you were trying to open the shower door, it's a very tight situation in there. Most hotel rooms in Tokyo are small. Still, I have stayed at another hotel that I think the bathroom space was better. Last time I stayed in Shibuya and I think if I was back, I might stay in Shibuya again over this location just because it seems more convenient where you can walk to everything in Shibuya. Even though Hilton offers a shuttle, it's just not as convenient to just walk outside to everything. So in the end location does matter. But if I had enough hilton points, I'd use them at this hotel again if I was in Tokyo again.

I would probably stay here again if returning to Tokyo in terms of the convenience of the hotel and being a good base for exploring Tokyo. The concierge service is excellent and helped me secure reservations to Teppan Baby, change the times and even find my lost sunglasses! Front desk were friendly and efficient, speaking excellent English. Breakfast was great. Zatta the first floor bar has a lovely view of night sakura and the friendliest most switched on staff! The ground floor cocktail bar is classy and has live jazz, a soothing place after a day of busy sightseeing. My only criticism is with departure - the lady at reception didn't coordinate our luggage very well so we were waiting at reception for a while even though we had woken up early so we could get a quick taxi to our next hotel.

Hilton is located in Shinjuku area of needed a long walk of 15min to pass through the big crowd before you get there. A closer train stop is Nishi-Shinjuku which is behind the hotel. The hotel also provides shuttle service to Shinjuku Station, much easier when you have luggages.

Daughter and I could have not had a more amazing experience than the one we had in the Hilton Tokyo. An amazing hospitality, great service, wonderful food. Beautiful decorations and just next to the start line of the Tokyo Marathon.

Top location, rooms are very small, very crowded and busy hotel, no proper advantages for hiltonhonors diamond member, wide range breakfast buffet, at the moment (4 months) no executive lounge - alternative is not adequate.

My wife and I stayed here for the majority of our stay in Tokyo. It's location is excellent, just a short walk through a tunnel to the Marunochi subway line. Plenty of food options within a short walk distance. Service was excellent (special shout out to Ernesto), and the rooms were excellent. The only downside is price, this is not a hotel to stay on a budget, but you get what you pay for here imo

Nice location in downtown. Easy to get to transportation options from subway to uber to taxi. Lots of great shops for tourist stuff but also some nice restaurants too if you are looking for convenience.

We selected the Hilton Tokyo as a good first base for our 3 week Japan trip. Our twin room was very comfortable. The hotel has great service. We enjoyed room service twice and it was prompt and delicious. We used the laundry service and while pricey it was convenient. There’s a shuttle bus to Shinjuku so you can get to anywhere in Tokyo conveniently. My only wish it that the shuttle started at 7 as opposed to 8. We had a couple of early morning tours and needed to use/pay for cabs instead. The hotel gets very very very busy on the weekend. Expect lines for the restaurants, elevators, shuttle bus and concierge. I’d recommend this property for staying in Shinjuku.

We started our trip with three of our grandchildren in Tokyo and chose the Hilton Tokyo because I had stayed there before when I was working. It had been a wild since being there, but I remembered it as being a really good place. I must say, it was beyond our expectations. Quality of the room and the food was only surpassed by the quality of the staff. This is the place to stay when in Tokyo. It is also very can be to the train and many of the sites.

I been there for a 2 nights on business trip, good facilities, good gym and good bars. It's interesting the restaurant when there was a special "strawberry afternoon tea".good connections with transportation, good place for a business trip

We stayed here with my 2 boys ages 9 and 13. We had 2 connecting rooms. The rooms are small so if you are traveling with children I could recommend getting a suite or 2 connecting rooms. The breakfast was fantastic. Location is great but its not really walking distance to the train station. It's a LONG walk so I would take an Uber or taxi. its a 10 min taxi ride from the JR Shinjuku train station.

We stayed at the Hilton Tokyo for 5 night an our stay was very good. As the executive lounge was not available before we left, I had been a bit apprehensive but we did not miss it. We choose to eat downstairs instead of on the 2nd floor as we were staying in a suite and did not regret it. Lots of options and well cooked food.

My daughter and I stayed here with a Luxury Escapes voucher. That was expensive enough as we had to pay an extra $200/night to stay on the nights we wanted. The hotel is way overpriced for what you get. The rooms are just the normal Hilton rooms that you get anywhere in the world. Not luxury like the Sofitel chain for example. For what we paid, we were expecting something really fantastic. I would have hated to pay what the hotel were asking. It was very busy and crowded every day. Breakfast was good but very busy. There was always a queue at the egg station which had only one chef. We caught the airport bus straight to the door which was great. The subway was within walking distance under the hotel. We had a meal at the Metropolitan Grill. It was nice, but definitely not worth the A$500 we paid - glass if wine $22, side dishes $17 each (mashed potato and asparagus) 100gm waygu steak and 120gm Australian steak $177!! Yes it was our fault, we didn’t do the maths before we ordered! We also had a set menu dinner at the Japanese restaurant there which was ok but nowhere near as good as the one I had in Bangkok. The staff were very friendly, helpful and professional. The location was the best thing about the hotel. As drinks and food are so expensive it may pay to have the all inclusive deal.

I wish I could take the bed home with me. I know you can purchase them directly from Hilton, but i did this one time, and it is not anyway as comfortable as these. we had a room on a top floor with a view, and that was nice. We did not like that the close was about 6 inches from the bed, so when someone is sleeping, the closet cannot be accessed. The breakfast was excellent. We could not find a place to get a before dinner drink. Both bars had private events going on until after dinner. That was a bummer!

The location and hospitatlity was outstanding. The staff was extremely friendly and professional. They went out of their way to ensure you were as comfortable as possible. Definitely will re-visit on our next trip.

This hotel has everything you could need and more. Right next to a station. Fabulous staff and decent buffet service plus complimentary transfers to Shinjuku city everyday as well as an airport shuttle. I would 100% stay here agin

Conveniently located near E and M lines, and a short walk to Shinjuku station, this is a good base to explore Tokyo.Breakfast was great, large selection, and brilliant omelettes!!Our king room was spacious (for Tokyo), and well equipped. Although; no power outlet or USB by the bed is poor in 2019 (Hilton - please dump the old iPhone connector alarm clocks and install a USB charger or something).Bar was good, but unfortunately, the bar staff came across as being in a bad mood, kind of aloof. A shame as all other staff were super.

Firstly, the Orange Limousine Bus stops at the Hilton Tokyo (from Narita or Haneda) so it makes it so convenient since you dont have to navigate through the subway system (specially if it's your first time). It has an underground walkway to the no 7 Nishi Shinjuku stop on the Marunouchi line and Oedo line (but I prefer walking above ground to the stops - it's a leisurely 5 minute walk to the stations). It is a 10 minute walk to Shijiku station and the Kabuchiko area (lots or restaurants/stores/clubs etc) It is so accessible and convenient and there is no need to take a cab or uber to get to where you want to go. They have a very knowledgeable concierge staff who have made restaurant resservations for me way before my arrival. And this has made my trips to Tokyo less stressful and more enjoyable. The buffet breakfast at the Marble Lounge is top notch! They provide Japanese and Western dishes and there is an abundance of food that you won't get bored for a week. For this stay I had requested, the concierge to make reservations at Yakiniku Jumbo. I would like to extend thanks to Ms. Arakawa, Ms. Sato and Mr. Nakamura for securing the reservation. The Concierge team has always assisted me in reservations even during my previous stays. I would also like to thank Ms. Chieni at the Concierge for assisting me in getting a prescription medication.Thank you for the delightful experience and I look forward to the reopening of the Executive Lounge before my next trip!

Positive:- The hotel is very beautiful and if you manage to get a good room from the higher floors the view can be stunning.- Gold member benefits. I checked in twice during my trip and the second time the room we got upgraded was really nice and spacious.- The all-round breakfast is really good (especially as it's included in the room fee for Gold members). Although it gets busy from time to time the staff manages the tables and service really well.- Check in and check out were super fast. I had ordered a pocket wifi for my trip and it was waiting for me in the reception as I checked in. Sweet!- Underground access to two metro stations and the free shuttle bus to Shinjuku station every 20 minutes.Negative:- The elevator trip from the top floors can sometimes take ages as the elevator makes 10 stops along the way.- The shuttle bus can sometimes get very crowded as certain groups decide to take it, leaving little to no room for others.- There was no heating in the toilet seat (or at least I couldn't figure it out).- No possibility to charge your phone next to the bed in all rooms.Neutral:- The area (Nishi-Shinjuku) is really quiet and safe - totally different from the east side of the Shinjuku station. This can be a positive or a negative thing depending on what you are looking for.It's likely that I'll stay here again.

My daughter and I spent a week in Tokyo and used the Hilton as our home base. Its location on two subway lines made it a perfect choice. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful, the room was spacious, and our stay was great. Highly recommended!

I could have spent all five days of my stay inside the hotel. There are several incredible restaurants. The breakfast buffet was the best I've ever seen, and I travel quite a bit. The staff were friendly and very helpful providing maps and directions to anyplace I wanted to go. There's access to the Metro in the basement. I couldn't find my way back to the hotel afterwards as most signs, naturally are not in English *Note most restaurants inside the hotel are so busy they require reservations.And the view!!! I will definitely stay again.

Room nice and simple. I think this hotel is more suitable for business man rather than for family. Its have shuttle bus to go and back to shinjuku station. Its really helpful. And can ride bus too to go to narita or haneda airport from the hotel. Very good.

This hotel really goes above and beyond in all aspects, truly has all the needs a business traveller would need. Gorgeous lobby, bed was exceptional, food recommendations that truly hit the spot. Love Tokyo and can't wait to come back!

It's our first time to stay downtown in Tokyo, and I was hoping to catch the Sakura viewing. We were a couple of days early, but still were able to enjoy some blossoms in the park nearby. The hotel is super busy all the time. The lobby has way more action going on than most hotels, every day there was a 50+ person lineup for their afternoon tea. With this kind of trade, there is little need to go beyond for your customers. So no upgrades, no late checkout, and not even a club lounge to visit. I'm not saying it was unprofessional or mismanaged, exactly the opposite; this hotel is a well-oiled machine that churns guests through with few hiccups. You don't go away feeling that anything was missing, nor do you get a feeling of being special. But for me, when I am spending more than $700 USD a night for a hotel, I generally find I go away feeling special or recognized in some way. I'll have to come back to Tokyo to see if that's the norm of the culture or just this hotel. Concierge was knowledgeable about the area and the shuttle to the train station was particularly useful. The room was a large suite for Japan, with a very comfortable king-sized bed and a huge shower with strong pressure and hot water. The tiny tub was only good for bathing children. Having two chairs at the desk was very useful for my wife and I both to be able to work on our computers, but the window blinds made the room have a bit of a prison like effect. I didn't get to try the pool, but had a feeling based on the buzzing activity at mealtimes in the hotel, that the guests in the pool would be like dumplings boiling in a pot.We took the train in from the airport and the limobus back. I have to say the train is the better choice if you suffer from car sickness.

I stayed in Tokyo on business and found the Hilton Tokyo great! Staff is great, rooms clean and comfortable, great location and the restaurants in the hotel and around well worth visiting. Word to the wise: if coming from Narita, do not take a cab. The drive is about 2 hours and will cost >$200 USD. If you book in advance, you can get a set rate of about $150 but still is not the way to go. The best choice is, after going through customs, look across the walkway to the left and get in line for the Limousine Bus service. For $29, you get a comfortable drive to the hotel getting dropped right in front. Maybe takes an addition 15-20 minutes but a great value! Alternatively, you can catch the train but that is a bit trickier.

The staff is exceptionally nice and professional. I usually stay at their executive level (package) which includes access to the executive lounge where they serve high quality pre-dinner food and drink. The hotel has a nice heated pool and Japanese bath.They also provide high quality Shiatsu massage. My only complain regarding my last stay is that they are renewing their executive lounge and pool and I didn't know until I arrived at the hotel.

OMG best ever - you can get a bus from nerita airport ( about 35$ ow) stayed 4 night AND DIDNOT WANT TO LEAVE - MUST GO BACKwill start with THE ROOM - first class super elite - the toilette with remote control that you just don't want to leave , seated heat WOW , Must take the lounge extra option Must try the japonaise breakfast - can stay at the hotel all day! the view from the loungeTHE SERVICE - wow , they are SO POLITE SO NICE SO WELCOMING ,

After our shake out run around the Imperial Palace we came to David's hotel to eat breakfast in the Marble Lounge. Perfect carbo loading for Tokyo marathon. The chef cooked some gluten free bread for Ron. Nothing was too much.
